The Mountain Goats show was, to be frank, fucking phenomenal. The caliber of 'fucking' I am not yet sure, and somewhere within this livejournal cut I will attempt to figure that out. I've read dozens of live reviews comparing the Mountain Goats live show to a religious experience. I'm not entirely sure I agree with those comparisons. Yes, a Mountain Goats show does have at least as much energy as a Southern Baptist service. Kraftbrau was as radiant as any chapel on a Sunday Morning, and John Darnielle played the part of a revered priest, with the audience clinging to his every word. But whereas a religious experience would typically imply sort of spiritual revelation, some sort of adoration for a higher-power that is all good and assures the world is all good; John Darnielle wishes to create no such revelations. A Mountain Goats song is a brilliantly crafted reflection on the phenomena within life and nothing more. It can be cathartic, harrowing, or even slightly absurd, but not once does John attempt to offer any solution to life's woes. John merely states them, often in form of narrative involving fictional characters, with an impeccable sense for detail, and creates scenarios that are rarely anything less than remarkable. He adroitly highlights his characters, their emotions and their plights; and in doing so frequently constructs elaborate blueprints of the human spirit at its worst. But what to do with these blueprints? Read them. Review them. Study them. Learn from them. But again, nothing is really presented to be learned. The only thing to be gained, and this is key, is an understanding of the fucked-up tendencies of the world around us. Love goes sour, shit goes awry; and in these situations there is often little more to do than acknowledge that love has gone sour or that shit has gone awry. And while John does frequently hint at his characters taking action or planning to take action, the key elements to his lyrics are still observational. They create worlds in which any listener can become a B-Grade actor, placing himself in the same scenario, looking around and saying, more or less, 'well, fuck.' If acceptance is the first step to overcoming a crisis, John focuses primarily on starting this process. This works to create a feeling of internal progression, and from there comes satisfaction and fulfillment. But there is no revelation or sage advice, nor is there a promise of better days ahead - the only thing promised is that there will be days ahead, but what will come out of them is uncertain and, you know, possibly bad. It is the embracement of the tumultuous nature of life and the tenacity of people in and of themselves, and this, I believe, is more immediate and visceral than a religious experience. A Mountain Goats show is not life-changing, but rather life-affirming. Of course, I've only now discussed how terrific the Mountain Goats are in general, and not how terrific they are as a live act in particular. I touted them as my favorite band at Pitchfork this summer, and I still firmly stand by that statement. I also proposed that they may be the best live act touring today, and while that may have been slightly brash, especially against more bombastic acts such as Broken Social Scene or the Arcade Fire, they're certainly a wholly distinct experience. Again, singing along with John is a better therapeutic exercise than lying on any couch. If part of the joy of a Mountain Goats song comes from becoming one of his characters, the entire night could be best described as a 250-person, simultaneous audition for about twenty different movies. John was, of course, by and far the best one there, and were Krafbrau a talent agency, he would have easily gotten the part every time; but that didn't deter any of us hopefuls, who were too caught up in our audition to care about anything else. I've affectionately described John's voice as "piercing," and I think that quality becomes even more apparent live. Again, this is not in a bad way (I don't think I could ever stomach casting a negative adjective John's way); it's a statement of prominence. John's voice has a timbre that is not only unique and instantly recognizable, but perfectly complementary to his lyric-centric music. He is able to, regardless of how hard he's pounding his acoustic guitar, send his words slicing mercilessly through his music and into the listener's ears; or, in the case of some of his slower work, leave it lightly dangling above gentle strumming. Yeah, he's not always perfectly in tune, and piercing is, again, not a word many people associate fondly with music; but his fervor, to me, is so perfectly complemented by this bizarre voice that I can't help but label John Darnielle as my favorite voice in all of music. Of course, as a Mountain Goats show, it was slightly bittersweet. I got to hear nearly 20 songs I love, and was unable to hear nearly 380 songs I also love. But it's impossible to complain about a Mountain Goats setlist. It would be the musical equivalent of being a rich, spoiled 8 year-old on Christmas who only got three of the trainsets he wanted and only two RC cars. It just seems fucking ridiculous to complain. My favorite trainsets: "This Year," "Dance Music," "Best Ever Death Metal Band in Denton," and, in a surprise move that really caught me off-guard, the song "Commandante" from the Devil in the Shortwave EP. I absolutely love that song, and everytime I listened to it I felt there would be no fucking way I'd ever see it live, and that depressed me. But was I ever wrong! Oh, and I'd be remiss if I didn't at least mention the terrific opening act by the name of Christine Fellows. She was - and this is, I've scientifically decided, the only adequate word to describe her - lovely. She wrote beautiful songs that were poppy yet fragile, and included no less than two songs featuring some hardcore ukulele shredding. She's easily one of my favorite opening acts to date. Also, John Darnielle made clear his love for Christine's music. During one of her songs - and, bear in mind, this is fairly effeminate, girly music - he went out into the crowd and started enthusiastically singing along. He was whipping his head around, which was especially goofy due to his new emo-core hair, belting out the lyrics, and waving his hand around in the air. All in all, he looked like a completely fucking psychotic fan, and that, I feel, was very awesome. The crowd at the Mountain Goats show was also, for the record, very cool. I was a little uneasy going into it, especially with the established stigma I've noticed in most people about going to concerts by themselves. As somebody who has now done it and wholeheartedly enjoyed it, I have to say that I don't understand this stigma; I guess at maybe some hardcore metal show where everybody wants to be a dick to everybody and it's survival of the fittest, yeah, I wouldn't want to go there alone. But that's not the case with most shows I go to, the Mountain Goats in particular. Everybody at this type of show has the intention of being super-cool to everybody around, and it's easy to get along with people when they wish to be super-cool to you. I also, in a highly improbable sequence of events, met some guy who goes to Central, which really caught me off-guard, because I didn't think the number of Mountain Goats fans at my school broke the double-digits. All in all, I would say that the Mountain Goats show was easily one of my favorite nights in recent memory. It was absolutely rejuvenating, and I would say it was exactly what I needed as a remedy to the frequent self-deprecation induced by Mt. Pleasant. I've now developed a two-part system to ascertain that I am, in fact, despite my obtuse detachment and romantic isolationism, a functioning human being, and it goes as follows: 1. I enjoy Jurassic Park 2. I find the Mountain Goats compelling Download: The Mountain Goats - Commandante Other, less important things I've done recently: I found out, earlier today, that I did not get the job at the Trout Hall front desk that I have been pursuing for the past few weeks. There was one opening and ten people being screened for the position; I was not good enough to best the other nine. In my defense, I had my screening the night after the Mountain Goats show, which discombobulated me beyond comprehension and left me feeling incoherent and incapable of counting money. So, to an extent, I could say the Mountain Goats cost me my job. And I would still say that it was more than worth it. I finished my first photojournalism project. And over the span of 80 pictures, and during my growing contempt for taking pictures, I managed to actually take a few that I'm fairly satisfied with. I've never taken anything more than a couple of snapshots, and I'm sure these are far from profound or even very good, but I feel like showing something for my labors, so fuck it, I'm posting a few of them. (warning: this picture may haunt you in your dreams) Oh, hey, also: Who's going home for Athens homecoming this year? I'm probably going, and I want more old college friends to be there so we can point at our high school football team and make snide remarks about how bad they are, just like the good ol' days. Everybody should go!

Dear Everybody Who Decided to Not See the Mountain Goats and Are Therefore Making Me Go By Myself, You guys are losers. Sincerely, Brian I've never been to a concert on my own before. It'll be odd to not have my usual social buffer, a group of people with whom to discuss meaningless drivel/how awesome that last song was during downtime, but I honestly don't think it will be too bad. It will be an interesting social experiment, at least; I'm not exactly the most extroverted of people, but in the right environment I can feel mildly comfortable around an entirely new set of people. Mild comfort is all I need. And it'll be a taste of what's to come in a few years when I'm done with college and leave this drab mitten state, foraging for some sort of habitat within a city where I will know nobody. Also, and this should go without saying, Mountain Goats fans are amongst the coolest people on the planet. This is a fact I've derived from a combination of the Pitchfork crowd, random commenters on the Peter Hughes livejournal, and my cousin. I'm sure the entire night will be swell, even if I don't know anybody going into it. I just need to look at it from this perspective: The less voice I waste on talking and trivial things like that, the more I'll have for singing. So there. But the Mountain Goats show, solitary as I will be, is a light at the end of the tunnel, and the tunnel is this weekend's work: In case you haven't heard, my classes are alright. I've got nothing against any of them, all of my professors seem coherent and intelligent, and, on the whole, the topics seem fairly interesting. All in all, nothing to really bitch about, which is why I haven't made a livejournal post about my classes yet. Everything is nice and unremarkable. I've just got a good portion of work which has, coincidentally, aligned itself to all be due within the same two-day period. I have a photojournalism project due on Monday, the criteria of which are 80 pictures of various things from various angles and the discovery of the 'joy of photography.' I also have two short articles due for my journalism class, and, granted, they're only 250 words, but they're also the first pieces of writing assigned for the class, and I don't want to totally botch them and cast 'totally fucking retarded' as my first impression on CMU's Journalism department. I've also got a handful of psych and philosophy reading for respective quizzes on the morning after the Mountain Goats show (hooray!). So I guess it's really not that bad. I can't even make it appear to be that bad. I wrote that last paragraph in the most extravagant manner I could, and even then it still came off sounding like not that big of a deal. I can't even make a mountain out of this molehill; the most I can do is create slightly elevated, rocky terrain. Oh, and one of my journalism articles is an obituary for myself. No, not a eulogy - that was an art I mastered last year thanks to HON 100B. This is slightly less bullshitty, and it actually serves the purpose of being a basic, introductory objective writing format. An obituary is slightly more elaborate (250 words as opposed to 55) and sheds a little more insight into the person's life. It also typically includes quotes from those who knew the deceased. You know where this is going. If I were to die tomorrow - or, more likely, Monday night when I drive back from the Mountain Goats at one in the morning by myself - what would you say to a reputable journalist asking you what you thought of me and my existence? It can be about anything: My passions, my personality, my hair. Whatever strikes your fancy.

And thus nearly four months of recalling and expanding upon the meaning of "doing absolutely jack shit" come to a close. This summer wasn't too bad - I had ample time to do nothing, worked a pretty alright job, and banked a decent amount of cash to squander on trivial expenditures over the next semester, placing myself in as bad a financial standing as when I started. But, hey, breaking even is a new record for me - all of last year I spent way more money than I should have, and I didn't even have much to begin with! I consider this to be a summer of progress. So now I'm getting myself ready for school. And I mean that in the vaguest way possible - this livejournal post, for example, is a vital part of getting myself ready for school. Actually packing shit? Pfft, I can throw that together in the morning. I'm planning on bringing only the barest of necessities up to school with me first trip, meaning toiletries, shit to keep me from dying, and clothes. Maybe a few DVDs and posters, but that's only because I never got around to unpacking them from when I moved out. My laziness has come full circle, and it has now turned into really, really advanced preparation. I've already made the concession of planning an "oh shit, I forgot to bring this, this, and this" trip right off the bat for a couple weekends down the line. I mean, there's no real use in trying to work around it. It's only going to be a matter of days before I'm sitting in my dorm room, sweating because I forgot a portable fan, and resting my head on my backpack because I forgot to pack a pillow. This will be an interesting couple of days, I think. My current goal is to manage to say "oh shit" fewer than a dozen times, but even I admit that's a bit unrealistic. I think I might start taking bets for the number of "oh shit"s I'll mutter. Closest guess gets a personal call on the phone from me, where I will say "oh shit" to you personally as I mooch off my roommate's toothpaste for the third time! What I think is most interesting about this night is the complete contrast between it and my last night at home a year ago. Last year, my last night in Troy was spent awake until the wee hours of the night, eyes glued open with both the anxiety and anticipation for college - new people, new town, new everything! Everything was neatly packed, and I was raring to go. This year my eyes are being forced open because I need to wait for my laundry to dry, and all excitement has been replaced with apathy and indifference. I've been to Mt. Pleasant for a full year - and, yeah, living around all-new people will be as much a kick as ever (nothing is more exciting than seeing somebody's facebook for the VERY FIRST TIME!!) - but I've also come to the realization that it's Mt. Pleasant. It's boring. I might work to try to fix that this year - maybe getting published, maybe being a little more active, maybe getting my good buddy John Vanderslice to come to visit (hey, he said he'd consider it if I emailed him, even though it was totally brought up as a joke) - but it's basically a more scholarly version of the same listlessness and boredom that permeates my life in Troy. Not that I want to stay in Troy, either. It's more of, when confronted with the prospect of moving back to Mt. Pleasant, my only response is, "why the fuck not?" That's more or less become my view on Mt. Pleasant after having both lived there and not lived there respectively: It's not a change for the better, nor is it a change for the worse; but it's a change I want solely because it's some variety of change. Next topic (and this is very important): If you ever got around to reading my last behemoth of a post, you'd remember me gushing about how great the Mountain Goats were, how much I love their music, and how I'd topple the ice cream cone of a poor orphan with cancer for a chance to see them again. Well, fortunately for me, I don't even have to touch a single orphan; The Mountain Goats just announced three new tour dates, and one of them is right in Michigan. The Kraftbrau Brewery in Kalamazoo, to be exact. Kraftbrau was the super-awesome place I saw John Vanderslice back in April, and aside from being one of the smallest, most intimate places I've been to, it was also one of the classiest in terms of decor. And also, it's a brewery, so woo, beer! The show is on Monday, September 18th. Tickets are 12 bucks ahead of time, 18 at the door, and doors open at 8 PM. Now, let me say this in the kindest way possible: If you live in Kalamazoo, or live in Mt. Pleasant while my car still has open seats, there is absolutely no excuse for you not to attend this show. I don't care that it's a Monday night, I don't care that you have a Tuesday super-ultra-final-exam-even-though-it's-only-three-weeks-in at 8 in the morning the next day; those are not acceptable reasons to miss The Mountain Goats. Anyway, even though it should be unnecessary to say this for everybody who could possibly go, and it should only be a matter of who gets to be one of the lucky few from Mt. Pleasant, let me know if you wanna come along. I'll order you a ticket when I get mine in a couple days. Everybody should come! If you aren't satisfied, well, I'm not worried about wasting your money, because you are a soulless shell of a human being with whom I will no longer be friends. Oh, I think my laundry might be done!

Back from Chicago. I guess I'm pretty tired. I was at Pitchfork all weekend, sweating profusely as the sun made its mark on my flesh, and I only got four hours of sleep last night, thanks to the temptation of Super Mario: The Lost Levels in Nick's room. I've also been holed up in a car for about five hours, taking a break only to refill gas and stomach. And, despite listening to several slow, mellow albums on the trip, I got very little sleep in the car; I found myself mostly stuck in the bothersome limbo between fully awake and fully asleep. Were dark circles under eyes as accurate a way of gauging human age as rings in an oak tree, I would be about a thousand years old, nearing my thousand and first birthday. By all means, I should have gone to bed when I got home. But I had CDs that I bought at the festival to import, posters to safely place in a wrinkle-free location on my desk, and a little unpacking to do. That, combined with the fact that I actually had to start my computer because I shut it off for the weekend (my computer being switched off is a rare occasion that occurs with the same frequency as a total solar eclipse), adding another five seconds to the total time it took me to do shit when I got home, put me in a state where I was no longer truly tired enough to sleep. Rather, I found myself in the same sleep limbo as before; minute after minute began to pass, the time for napping ceasing to be reasonable, and I decided to rough it until I call it an early night tonight. So that's where that puts me right now. I may not have slept, but I've done the next best thing - ingested perhaps the most sugar-filled substance on the planet: Marshmallow Fruit Loops, a cereal designed by people who firmly believed that standard Fruit Loops, pure sugar with a hint of artificial fruit flavoring, were not sugary enough. Three or four cavities later, I felt like a new man. But my mild sugar high, the only thing keeping me fully alert at a time like this, is not the point of this update. I'm here to write about the Pitchfork Music Festival, the reason I was in Chicago in the first place. Though, before I start, I need to once again place a secondary emphasis of this entry on Super Mario: The Lost Levels, the reason I stayed up until 2:30 in the morning with a 7:00 AM wake-up. That game is such a bitch. Okay, moving on: Nate wrote what I would consider a very good guide of Pitchfork in his journal(I don't know how to do fancy livejournal-to-livejournal links, and I'm certainly not willing to spend the energy, currently a precious commodity, to find out), and I'm hesitant to lauch into a full guide for the sake of sounding repetitious to those who read both of our journals (read: 90% of people who read this). I also know for fact that Dan is working on one. But I can't resist. I'll try to avoid treading the same ground, making the same statements of awesomeivity; ideally, both of our guides will feel fresh to anybody bored enough to read both in their entirety. After all, this is just another drop in what will eventually become an ocean of blog entries on the festival - what can one more hurt? But I digress. This introduction has gone on long enough. We left our humble abode of Troy at 11 in the morning to set out for the bustling city of Chicago - and, more specifically, it's slightly less bustling suburb of Oak Park, where we were to meet Nick (Nate's roommate), who volunteered his house as a place for us to stay. The trip, consisting of me, Nate, Dan, and Cory all in Cory's 300M, was more or less standard teenager roadtrip fare. A bunch of guys making meaningless conversation, cringing at every gas sign passing by; the usual. Sans a couple of rough spots of traffic - and let's be realistic, what would a road trip be without SOME point to curse profusely at the the jackhole riding the left lane to its very end, despite several signs indicating its terminal state? - we got there without a hitch. Then we got to Nick's, which was, and I mean this with as much sincerity as possible for a deadbeat like myself, as nice of a place as we could have ever hoped to stay. First thing's first: I was expecting a place on the floor to crash. That's it. Maybe a pillow and a blanket if his parents were nice. But what they had far exceeded my wildest dreams of places in which I could dream more wild dreams - four beds. One for each of us. As guests. A luxurious guest room, complete with a collection of old-school Nintendo stuff (though, as I found out, that was an accursed vice - damn you, The Lost Levels!). And his parents were tremendously nice and helpful with our complete and utter lack of knowledge of Chicago. I think it's safe to say that, were it not for them, not only would we have paid an absurd amount in hotel fees, but we also would have killed an absurd amount of time trying to figure out train routes to the place. AND they had two big, full boxes of Honey Nut Cheerios - they know how to stock a cupboard. We arrived around 5 or so their time, so we had a little time to kill in the city for the night. Despite it being muggy as hell and being crammed in the backseat of Cory's car with three other people (we met up with a couple of Nate's other U of M friends around the city), it was an amazing sight. I've never really, truly taken a look around Chicago. The closest I've been was a fruitless, heartbreaking search of Michigan Avenue for a certain famous man's statue a year ago, and that left me with nothing but contempt for the city. This trip managed to turn that contempt into sheer admiration - that city is phenomenal, and particularly pretty at night, when, and I'm convinced they leave on at least a handful of lights in their buildings for show, the buildings illuminate the skyline as a humble moon sits in the backdrop, robbed of its duty of lighting the night sky. We hit up a few major landmarks: This shiny bean-thing, a giant fountain, some harbor with a bunch of boats, and, most importantly of all, this little trough of running water for us to dip our feet in, which was significantly more refreshing than I had anticipated. After our brief excursion into the city proper, we returned to the quiet suburb of Oak Park where we ordered some Chicago deep-dish pizza from a legitimate, ritzy pizza chain. Were these the intestines of a lesser man, I would have keeled over from the intensity of the cheese, crust, and sauce; but mustering all my will I managed to down two full slices of the stuff. To give a proper image of the deceptive nature of a stuffed, deep-dish Chicago pizza: Imagine one of my entries, looking sufficiently long enough before clicking on the cuts, and then imagine your first bite as when you click on a cut for the first time - holy fuck. I'm sure the pizza is terribly unhealthy, but I consider part of that unhealthiness off-set by the total work-out I had getting the food down my throat, into my intestines, and, in the grand scheme of things, into the toilet. The pizza, of course, knocked me out cold. It wasn't more than a half an hour after I finished my second slice before I was in bed with eyes closed, readying myself for the two intense days ahead. These two days were ridden with amazing music, hip cats, and rockin' merch. I saw a grand total of 10 bands over the two days: Hot Machines, Man Man, The Mountain Goats, Destroyer, The Futureheads, Tapes n Tapes, Danielson, The National, Devendra Banhart, and Spoon. I'm tempted to write on them in order of appearance, but that's not quite as much fun - I want to save my most extravagant praise for last. And there are an even 10 bands up there, making the bothersome rock journalist cliche of ranking shit impossible for me to resist. To make up for it, I'll include a shiny picture and mp3 link with each band (and for the concerned, I promise you this is the closest I will ever, ever, ever get to making this an mp3 blog). This is the Pitchfork Music Festival, through my eyes, in order of importance: ----------------------------------------------- 10. Hot Machines Okay, it's not totally fair to include these guys. The only reason I saw them was because they were the first act, I had checked out the merch tent to a suitable extent for the time being, and I was bored. They weren't particularly helpful with solving the last of my complaints - this band did very little for me. What they offered was a smoldering series of chords pounded out through a heavily distorted guitar to some chick's screeching vocals; if the Hot Machine they were referring to was a teapot about to boil over, they did a splendid job of living up to their name. Though I don't mean to be too hard on the guys. They weren't absolutely terrible, and while I didn't particularly enjoy their music, I was, on occasion, able to tap my toe along to it. And if you consider them as a relative opener for the vastly superior act of Man Man, they weren't bad by those standards. I've seen some dismal openers, from the deafening Les Os to the awkward Gold in Chains, and the fact that I was able to not cringe the entire time made them alright at what they were doing. After all, Man Man was on that stage a half an hour after their set, and I waited for Man Man the entire time. For the sake of kindness, I'll treat them like an opener; and in that regard, they were satisfactory at getting me ready for the onslaught of way slicker noise that would be Man Man. Download: Ah, forget it, I don't care enough to dig up an mp3 of this band for you to listen to. If you're a huge fan of all this post-punk hubub, look 'em up yourself. 9. Danielson Alright, now we're talking: This is the first of the bands listed that I was very interested in. Danielson's Ships is a fun record: An art-rock explosion, reminding me of what would happen if you mixed one-part Animal Collective and one-part Polyphonic Spree. I'm unfamilair with their prior work, but I know that I like the tracks off Ships, and that's entirely what they delivered to the audience. Combine that with their slick uniforms, the novel fact that the majority of them are related (fun fact to make your friends at the show go 'oooh, aaah'), and you've got yourself a solid, live set. The band brought their eclectic, scatterbrained tunes to life terrifically well. The show also offered some of the best hand-clapping of the entire festival, knocking The Futureheads (more on that, obviously, later in the update) show off of its throne as hand-clapping champ. Alright, fair enough, maybe the clapping wasn't as intense as that offered by those charming Brits, but it offered a more interesting mix of clapping. The Futureheads, like most conventional rock shows, stuck to conventional clapping methods of either downbeats or upbeats; Danielson, being the crazy art-rock collective they are, didn't make the effort to define when to do which for us. In fact, they encouraged us to do both, which left one-third of the audience doing downbeats, one-third doing upbeats, and another third, myself included, not sure when the fuck to clap and occasionally just saying fuck it and clapping on the eighth-note. There was, however, a particularly charming time when Dan, Cory, and Nick were doing downbeats while Nate and myself were doing upbeats - never has there been a more powerful audience rhythm section! All in all, a slick act from a group that must be the highlight of every family reunion. Download: Danielson - Did I Step on Your Trumpet? 8. Tapes n Tapes I'm legitimately afraid to list these guys as number 8. Why, you ask? You never saw the guy announcing them; whereas most other bands had the same, slightly psychotic-but-toned-down-this-year-and-reasonable-now guy bringing them on stage, Tapes n Tapes had a publicist all their own - and he was intimidating. Prior to the show, the standard announcer handed the mic to a very assertive Indian man, who, and I quote, "[introduced] a band that, if bands had cocks, would have a giant one" He went on to ascertain our loyalty to the group's massive phallace: He kindly instructed us to, and again I quote, "Blog about this band. Post mp3's about this band. Fuckin' spread the word. If I catch you not blogging about this group, I will come to your house and kill your dog. And if you don't have a dog, I will hurt the weakest member of your family." I have two dogs, making me doubly scared. Don't get me wrong, crazy Indian announcer man - Tapes n Tapes put on a great set. In fact, every one of these bands, sans Hot Machines, put on some of the best shows I've ever seen. I can't say a single one of my top 9 was a disappointment. Tapes n Tapes churns out some fine, catchy indie rock tunes, and they were great to see live. The one member played a mean tuba, which was a pleasant surprise (I didn't think it was ACTUALLY tuba on the album), and the rest of the band played their parts exquisitely, getting nearly every head nodding and toe tapping. Also, the keyboardist/tubist had the Wrens shirt I just bought a day earlier, so I even felt a personal connection to the guys. They were good. Seriously. And I'm posting an mp3, meaning that I'm fuckin' spreading the word. Please don't hurt my dogs. Download: Tapes n Tapes - Insistor 7. Devendra Banhart Man, I wish I could be a hippie. A legitimate, professional hippie in any branch of the arts - be it painting, sculpting, or, in this case, music. Just getting to sit around, looking at shit, finding this shit really awesome, growing my hair out, and drowning myself in a variety of harmful substances; that would be the life. Unfortunately, I'm not remotely talented in any regard, so I have to live my hippie dreams vicariously through Devendra. Before I go on, in case you're not familiar with Mr. Banhart, I'd like you to take another good look at that picture. And I mean really look at it: Look at his eyes, his scraggly beard, his goofy grin. Look at it in the way that you would think he would look at a picture. Once you get a grasp of his mindset via that picture, thereby giving finally giving you an understanding of how to stare at the picture in the first place, everything will piece together; you will look at the picture, and you yourself will cave in to giving a goofy, ecstatic grin. It's not challenging to imagine Devendra as an iconic figure of some freak-folk revivalist movement. He's got the personality for it, his band's got the liquor for it, and, dammit, he's a good enough songwriter for the task. His tracks, backed by his motley crew of hippies, one of whom could almost rival Devendra in a beard/hair scraggly contest, brought the crowd to life, giving me a taste of what must have been similar to a smaller, more respectable Woodstock '69. I'm definitely considering checking out more of his music now, considering that I've only heard portions of his earlier albums, and only listened through Cripple Crow, his latest, once. The coolest part of the set, however, was not one of his songs, but rather the fact that he picked an audience member at random out of a sea of volunteers to come on stage to play a song of his own. I thought it was a joke at first; after all, while he's a total hippie, isn't this a bit TOO much for a festival of this size? Clearly not. In what must have been the single greatest moment of his life, he played a song in front of 20,000 people. And for a dude picked out from the audience at random, he was damn good, too. The fact that he was able to do his song without shitting himself at least three times is commendable, but actually playing a good, not just decent or cute 'aww, thank you for trying', song? Phenomenal. If you're into folk, check out his myspace: Molotov Pipedream. Devendra then came back on stage, did a closer, much hand clapping was had, much pot was smoked. The audience gave an outstanding ovation as he left after his finale, presumably to go back stage and drink and smoke. Ah. What a life. Download: Devendra Banhart - Chinese Children 6. The Futureheads What a charming bunch of gents. The Futureheads play rock music. That's all there is to it. They play fun, catchy rock tunes. What seperates them from every other rock group writing a decent hook or melody, though, is their vocal prowess: Were you to play, say, a Franz Ferdinand track and loop it over with an ocapella group, this would be the result. Their personalities simply radiate energy, and once all of them chime in vocally at once, there's no denying it: This is a killer show. As mentioned in Danielson, The Futureheads did a great job of getting everyone up and clapping. They also had a neat little segment, which was lovingly referred to as a game, in which the audience sang the vocal harmonies; half of the audience covering one part, the other half covering the second. All in all, though, they seemed to realize a crucial fact that all the best live acts acknowledge: The more interested the audience is, the more energetic the show, and the more enjoyable it is for them to perform. Needless to say, they were having a blast. Download: The Futureheads - Decent Days and Nights 5. Destroyer Wait, what? Yes, you're reading correctly. I'm only half way through the list, and Destroyer is already being brought up. This must be a shock coming from a devoted Dan Bejar acolyte such as myself. And this is true; I'm honestly a bit shocked that Destroyer isn't gunning for number one, but as it turns out, Bejar's live act was simply out done by others at the festival. As far as on album goes, Destroyer is still tied with The Mountain Goats in terms of my favorite group at the festival. If you've ever listened to Destroyer, Bejar comes across as somewhat of a lovable madman: Quivering voice accompanied by unconventional pop arrangements and whimsical, verbose lyrics, this man almost seems as if he'd be a total recluse. And live, well, he kind of is. He let out one line of banter throughout the entire set: "This song is about... uh..." That's it. We never really got to find out what the song was about, which would have actually been groundbreaking, as nearly every Destroyer song is a complete enigma surrounded by a labyrinth of self-referential lyrics. Maybe that one line of banter is fitting for Destroyer, a band which offers its fans that line as the only possible answer to being asked the meaning of a song. Maybe that one line of banter is the pinnacle of Destroyer self-referentialism, as he brilliantly summarizes his entire discography in one simple line. That's got to be it. His songs were fairly straightforward, with a couple of new parts added here and there, and he certainly did a fine job of performing them. He just didn't bother creating any sort of stage presence at all; but then again, maybe that only enhances the mystery of Destroyer, creating the greatest stage presence of all? I could pontificate on this all day, but the bottomline is, regardless of metaphorical intent, his set just wasn't as exciting as the four I've yet to name. That said, I definitely felt super cool and hip knowing a decent amount of lyrics, allowing me to sing along at one of the most lyrically challenging shows on the planet. Knowing even a portion of his lyrics is indeed something in which I pride myself. And, even with Dan's befuddling stage "presence", this was the loudest I've ever been able to listen to a Destroyer album, and that alone is enough to skyrocket it to the top half of my list. Download: Destroyer - Painter in Your Pocket 4. Man Man YES! That's all I could utter when I saw Honus Honus, frontman of Man Man, enter the stage during set-up dressed in short shorts, a headband, a tight shirt reading "EAT MORE PAINT", and aviators; oh, and lest we forget, his moustache. Honus has a moustache that would make even John Stossel quiver in fear; a crop of facial hair so bold that it must require some sort of facial hair brush, not a comb, to get it in order. The rest of the band was, for the most part, equally bearded, though nothing was quite as exceptional as the aforementioned 'stache. Of course, while their outfits initially excited me and had me prepared for an intense show, little did I expect that they would return from setting up wearing Indian warpaint. This, and this alone, dictated that these men were not here to fuck around: They were here to defend their libidos and testosterone as if war had been declared upon them. Their first song was little more than manly, manly noise: A collage of xylaphone, keyboard, saxaphone, and a drumset that was little more than random shit being hit into other random shit. Then Honus's voice came in, which is the most masculine growl I've ever heard, bar none. Once the two came together in perfect unison, a perfect combination of manly noises and manly vocal, something kicked in - that thing was my ass, and Man Man was doing the kicking. Their show only got more incredibly and ridiculous as the set went on, as the band brought feathers to throw into the crowd as they ran about the stage. Oftentimes, there were two or more percussionists, for the necessity that is smashing shit into shit that makes the Man Man sound. As Honus growled over his cacophony, the crowd could only stand back in awe: This really was the finest exhibition of manliness ever seen. Man Man's performance can be summarized in one single act: The silverware Honus brought out on stage. It was a bowl, filled with silverware. That was it. He set it on his keyboard bench, took out a piece, and threw it into the other ones in the bowl. The silverware went flying everywhere out of the bowl, not even making a very loud sound. He gathered his forks, knives, and spoons, put them back in the bowl, and did it again. He did this about four or five times. Why? Because he's a man, man. Download: Man Man - Engwish Bwood 3. The National I can't for the life of me figure out why I didn't start listening to these guys earlier. I only just got their 2005 album, Alligator, little over a month ago. I got into some of their back catalogue afterward, but I'm still primarily an Alligator fan - The National are able to pump out powerful rock songs bustling with emotional intensity intertwined between songs that are a bit more subdued but still tremendously addictive. The singer has a crooning baratone which is able to switch over to one of the tactful uses of the rock scream I've ever heard, and the rest of the band is able to play music that is everybit as catchy as it is powerful. As a general rule of thumb, high-octane on album equals phenomenal live show. As a result, we skipped Jens Lekman (who, in all honestly, looked like a very good act and I regret having to miss him, but it was worth it) to secure a good third-fourth row spot for the set. The wait was more than worthwhile; The National played what could honestly be considered one of the most powerful sets of the afternoon, with the singer looking as if he was having spasms running through his body any time he had to kick into a chorus on the louder tunes. The whole set was remarkable, but the highlights were "Abel" and "Mr. November," the latter of which offering the most rousing chorus this side of the Mountain Goats (gee, haven't seen them yet. Wonder where they could be on the list?) "Mr. November" was also the primary cause of me losing my voice on Sunday, as screaming "I'M MR. NOVEMBER, I WON'T FUCK US OVER, I'M MR. NOVEMBER" at the top of your lungs several times becomes a bit taxing on the vocal chords. The singer deserves some major applause for stamina. The only real perplexing thing about their set was the fact that they DIDN'T close with "Mr. November," a song that I would literally consider one of the best closers a band could ever write. Rather, they closed with a slower song from one of their earlier albums. Maybe the singer needed a vocal warm-down from all his wailing during "Mr. November," and this was to keep him from losing his voice all together. That's the only real logical explanation I can think of. Download: The National - Mr. November 2. Spoon Ah, Spoon. Inarguably one of the best straight-forward rock groups of our time, they've got it down to a science: Their songs contain a well-oiled rhythm section, some slick guitar playing, and Britt Daniel's grizzled, rockin' vocals. They've also managed to pioneer a sound all their own. A Spoon song is unmistakenably a Spoon song, as a result of a product that is greater than a sum of its parts. Everything just falls together perfectly. Spoon even sampled a new song for the crowd, and it sounded as fresh and catchy as ever, while still maintaining the certain level of familiarity that comes with the Spoon sound. So, as no surprise, a band so crisp and pristine in their song-writing and production had a slick, terrific live show. Britt Daniels has obviously got a killer set of pipes on him - the albums make that perfectly clear to the listener. But what becomes more apparent live is the how talented a guitarist Britt Daniels is. I never realized how amazingly well he could, to use guitar cliche terminology (in my defense, I am describing a fairly straight-forward, guitar-based rock group), shred. He's also, as would be assumed for the rocker he is, got the rocker swag down, too. Whereas I'd say Gustav is the ideal long-haired rocker, Britt is the posterboy for the shorthair rockstar; his hair was disheveled to the point of flying straight up over about half of his head by the end of the show, and they only apropos way to describe it would be 'rock and roll.' Him and his band all had terrific stage presence, and it was no challenge to get the audience moving. They played their songs. They played them well. They offered a great level of energy. What more could I possibly ask for? Meeting Britt Daniels, you say? Because I did that, too. After the set, rather than trying to squeeze in for a spot for Os Mutantes (they sounded like they were putting on a fine show, but man, we were fuckin' tired), we decided to take a seat for a while. A few minutes later, we noticed Britt hanging around the front of the stage, signing posters and whatnot. Unfortunately, I didn't get one of the free Spoon posters being distributed at the merch tent - Cory had one and I already had three others to my name - so I had to improvise. I needed to get SOMETHING signed by Britt, no question about that. The only thing I could really think of at the time was one of my gas receipts from the trip, and the more I thought about it the better the idea sounded. I'll eventually have to pay the bill on that thing, and what better way to console myself after spending over three dollars a gallon than to have a reminder right on the receipt of why it was all worth it? So I had Britt Daniels sign my receipt. I didn't hold him up for long - he had other, more deserving fans to attend to - but I told him he played a killer set, shook his hand, and took my receipt, which read, "Thank Bush, Brett". Cool guy. Download: Spoon - The Two Sides of Monsieur Valentine

1. The Mountain Goats

 It's interesting: For the last four bands, I've had a very hard time placing them in order. Everything between Destroyer and Spoon put on a live show of about equal sublimity, often coming down to the point where it was borderline nitpicking. But picking the number one group of the festival was easy for me. Nothing even came close to touching The Mountain Goats performance; not even Britt Daniel's rocking, Destroyer's indecisiveness, Man Man's manliness. John Darnielle and Peter Hughes trumped all of that in what is, undoubtedly, the single greatest 50 minutes I have ever spent outside. The set opened, surprisingly, with "Jenny", a track off of the terrific All Hail West Texas. I wasn't totally expecting that - I was expecting him to go with something more recent, as an something off of The Sunset Tree or We Shall All Be Healed. But I can't complain, because "Jenny" is one of my favorite Mountain Goats tracks, and it was a great opener - from the first time yelling "It's the pirate's life for me!" the entire audience was sold on Darnielle's intricate tales. A Mountain Goats show is made infinitely better with knowledge of the lyrics. This is something I was kind of expecting, but not to this extent - I knew my decent knowledge of Mountain Goats lyrics would come in handy, but I didn't know it would enhance the show nearly as much as it did. There's something magical that comes with singing along with John and a crowd full of equally eager, excited Mountain Goats fans. Singing the choruses to nearly half of his songs is some of the best catharic release a show could offer, giving a borderline therapeutic effect. I'm convinced that if somebody sat down the angriest man in the world - the craziest sociopath, the bitterest serial killer - with John Darnielle, a handful of other people, and a lyric sheet, he would feel perfectly fine at the end of it. In fact, he would be one of the happiest, most relieved men on the planet, all through John's poetry in action. I've long felt that John Darnielle is the single greatest thing to happen to the acoustic guitar, and seeing the Goats live has only proved it. I'd also propose that John Darnelle is one of the greatest things to happen to the pen as well, as his lyrics are some of the best poetry of any genre - music or otherwise - and any era. He has a knack for description, always allowing just the perfect amount, and none of his words seem out of place. Watching John write a song must be like watching a Tetris screen filled evenly with blocks all the way up the screen, sans for the line closest to the left; when John begins to write, it's as if he gets four straight, vertical pieces in a row. And instead of that lame, Russian jig music in the background, it's a perfect combination of acoustic strumming and Peter Hughes on the bass, possibly with a few other instruments and Vanderslice hanging out if we're dealing with one of the newer, cleaner albums. "No Children" alone would have been enough to justify the 70 dollars it took to get to Chicago to see the Pitchfork Music Festival. Never have I felt a song so powerful, so raw, as John's from the point when he began with, "I hope that our few remaining friends give up on trying to save us" to, "I hope we both die." It's challenging to pick a climax of the song: Would it be "hand in unlovable hand"? "I hope the worst isn't over"? "There is no sight of land"? Fuck it, it's impossible to pinpoint a certain part of the song - the entire thing carried the energy and efficacy of a climax for nearly three minutes. That is the power John Darnielle's pen and guitar, when used in tandem, carries. And, to think, I went into the Mountain Goats determined to hear both "Going to Georgia" and "The Best Ever Death Metal Band in Denton," neither of which were played by the Goats. I can't complain about the setlist, per se; he covered the gamut of his career, from new material to a song off his very first 7", and it's almost a curse when you have as many memorable, fantastic songs as the Goats. I could have listened to them play for hours without showing even the slightest disinterest; unfortunately for me, they're not only human but also on a strict time schedule, so the set had to be cut short without giving me a chance to hear either of those songs. And even missing what I consider two tremendous Mountain Goats staples, I would still consider it by far the best set of the day, and tied with The Arcade Fire and Broken Social Scene for the greatest live show I have ever seen. It's especially impressive to think that the Goats could be as mindblowing at a festival as either of those bands in a designated venue. The Goats were under strict time restraint, the crowd was bigger, the sun was present; individual festival shows are, typically, on the whole weaker than a small venue show. Yet John Darnielle was able to prove that he has one of the most memorable voices in all of music, and it didn't matter how much time they had, how big the crowd was, or how blistering the sun was. Peter Hughes was able to perfectly compliment his songcraft with his bouncy, infectious bass lines. And that other guy? He could play a mean keyboard. I would from this say that, in theory, the Mountain Goats are the single greatest live act performing today, possibly ever. If I am ever able to catch the Mountain Goats at a solo show - like the one they did at Krafbrau that was 21+ last October ($%#$%$#!!!) - when they're given the time to expand, cover more of their music, and have a more intimate setting, it would undoubtedly be breathtaking. And I say that even moreso because it would take a lot of breath to keep singing the entire night. Download: The Mountain Goats - No Children (still intense on album!) ----------------------------------------------- And that was Pitchfork, in terms of live shows. Plenty of great stuff, some phenomenal stuff; all in all, a weekend of sunburning and sweating well-spent. There were, regretably, a few acts I would have liked to see that I didn't for the sake of another band of the overwhelming need for food and water. The most notable of those being Art Brut, Jens Lekman, and the Silver Jews. Art Brut had to be missed because it was going on 5:30 and none of us had eaten a single thing, plus we were just at Destroyer for his entire set, making it impossible to get a decent spot for Art Brut, who immediately followed him. Jens had to be missed, as previously stated, for The National. And Silver Jews, while we still couldn't have gotten a very good spot because it was the last act of the day and we had just watched the Futureheads in entirety, had to be missed because all of my friends were whining to leave because they wanted food, drinks, and some of those other petty things necessary for survival. I heard some of Silver Jews from the trainstation a few blocks away, and it, unfortunately, sounded pretty good. It's a shame my friends are a bunch of Silver Anti-Semites. I also grabbed myself some merchandise, but for my sake since I've been working on this entry for nearly five hours now between writing and getting pictures and mp3's, I'll be brief: 2 T-shirts: One of The National, one of The Wrens (hooray!) 3 albums: Destroyer - Destroyer's Rubies, Okay - High Road, Silver Jews - The Natural Bridge Free posters: Destroyer, Arcade Fire, Silver Jews The t-shirts are self-explanatory and awesome. The CD's have so far all been great purchases. The Silver Jews disc was bought because I had only heard American Water going into the festival, and despite my love for it, I had yet to hear anything else by them; this was instantly remedied with this purchase. The album's a bit more spacious and lethargic than American Water, and I honestly prefer the latter, but it's still a solid album to listen to when I'm feeling at my most listless. And it's also got the single greatest lyric of all-time: "a robot walks into a bar orders a drink lays down a bill the bartender says, 'hey, we don't serve robots' and the robot says, 'oh, but someday you will'" It's also bustling with some other great lines, but I don't want to be here forever quoting Silver Jews. Just know that that's the best of them, and there's no beating that. Period. Sorry, John Darnielle. Love your lyrics, but you just can't top that one. The Okay album was recommended to me by the dude at the Absolutely Kosher booth, and I'm glad I decided to take the 12 dollar plunge. It's a neat little album, consisting twisted pop arrangements with a tinge of euphoria (a tinge? euphoria? how does that work? I don't totally know), but I can definitely see why he recommended it to me based off of Sunset Rubdown and Frog Eyes. The dude's voice also sounds like somewhat of a mix between Baxter (the fly bad guy) from Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and Dan Bejar. It's an interesting blend. And Destroyer's Rubies is my favorite album of 2006 so far. I've had it for months. It was very good then, and it is still very good now. And now I've got a shiny booklet with it. Last but not least, I really do feel some kind of obligation to pay tribute to the crowd at Pitchfork. The announcer, while frequently mocked for making the festival up to be something greater than it really is (though in smaller doses than last year), is partially right: The community at Pitchfork is really unlike any other. Everybody is nice, courteous, and a general blast to be around. It's also nice to have a greater knowledge of music this year than I did last. While I still don't consider myself an expert by any regard, I now feel that I'm able to carry a musical conversation without feeling like I'm dulling the recipient. I had a good chat with the guy at the Absolutely Kosher booth, where he got me more excited than ever for the Swan Lake album (Dan Bejar, Spencer Krug (wolf parade), Carey Mercer (frog eyes)) by saying that he's heard it and it's phenomenal. And I also met the guy who cofounded the Destroyer Wiki or something along those lines while getting my legit copy of Rubies; and the Destroyer Wiki is the most awesome Destroyer website of all time, since it annotates his lyrics with all possible references, so I gotta say, I admire the man. So that's that. Until next year. That took around five hours. I'm done. Nothing else has happened in my life. Period.

I remember there was a time when I considered it taboo to go a week without writing in my livejournal; now I'm going a month and a half without even batting an eyelash. Maybe it's because my life has slowed to a crawl, maybe it's because it's summer and my life is a constant hustle and bustle (ha), or maybe it's because I'm not nearly as prolific a livejournalist as I once was. Or maybe, despite the first two possibilities being ostensibly contradictory, it's a combination of all three. I wouldn't consider my life as of late exciting. But I do have a job, which is relatively limiting. Time I would spend writing about the insignificant and trivial events of my life is now spent delivering food to hungry guests at Red Lobster. I suppose it's a mildly noble endeavor - and by "noble", I mean it makes me money, which is, so I've been told, the most noble and selfless of causes. I'm finally a waiter. I didn't update during my training period, and I don't intend to elaborate on it now, weeks after the fact; but know this: I didn't get fired. I managed to make it through training at Red Lobster, which I've been told by numerous employees who have worked numerous server jobs, is a rough and hectic position, especially for somebody who's never worked a server job before. Let alone any job. So, despite a couple of rough patches during training and being hired nearly on charisma alone, I made it through with relatively few scrapes and bruises - on both me and my guests. The cash flow seems to be pretty decent. Yeah, $2.65 an hour - that's a bit of a downer. But the tips are, in fact, quite good. I'm still working a two table section, which can occasionally slow to a crawl - the upside being, of course, that it can only speed up to a comfortable power walk, which is good for a newbie waiter like myself - but it's fairly bad on tips. That said, I've walked out of the restaurant with a decent chunk of change in my pocket after a couple of shifts. And I can only expect it to improve from there, as they, I hope, deem myself suited for a full-fledged three-table section, complete with stuff to do at all points of my shift instead of at sporadic intervals. Anyway, that's about all there is to say about my job. It's not bad work - it's still work, which I'm against by principle, but I can't complain. It's money, and I can definitely take another month of it before heading back to school. And it does give me the occasional interesting story to tell - something I've been lacking since school has ended. I've got a handful of them, and odds are, given my primarily local readerbase, I've already told you most of them, but I'll divulge the best of them here: The homeless guy. It was 7:00 at night, nearly an hour after I started my shift as a food walker as part of my training. It was a slow night - the restaurant was relatively empty for a Saturday evening, and I, as a food walker, had next to absolutely nothing to do. My heart began to yearn for excitement, and, fortunately, God heard my yawns. Shortly after I acknowledged the night as boring as fuck, one of the waitresses burst into the alley complaining that she was just sat some crazy homeless son of a bitch, he was trying to tell her about every single injury he has ever received (she wanted to augment his stories with a couple of her own), and he looked like he was going to take up one of her tables for the rest of the night. Most of the alley simply sympathized with her complaints; everybody except for one other waitress, who took her pathos much deeper than the rest of us, recalling a similar occurrence happening to her nearly three years ago. The second waitress recalled this crazy homeless motherfucker, fitting the same scraggly disposition described of this crazy homeless son of a bitch, occupying one of her tables for nearly five hours and then attempting a walk-out. He was caught, of course, which would lead one to believe that he wouldn't have the gall to step back in the restaurant after being blacklisted as a walk-out. But she was curious. So she walked out, glanced at his table, and came running back into the alley, screaming, "I CAN'T BELIEVE IT, IT'S HIM!" After the five minutes it took for everybody to wrap their minds around this overwhelming coincidence, the first waitress decided to get one of the managers to watch after him. At this point, the manager approached the man, told him that he would after to see some cash before he ordered another bottle of wine and a lobster or two, and immediately took patrol of the entrance. The homeless guy started sweating bullets, as he realized that he had been pegged. But he wasn't going to give up quite yet - he kept his eye on the door, waiting for the manager to take a single second away from it. Well, the manager walked around the door for a good five-ten minutes before realizing that, you know, something has gotta been done. So he decided to give the guy a chance to make a break for it. The manager feigned a quick step outside, and the man without hesitation made a scramble to the front door; he was immediately stopped by a wily manager, who told the man that he'd need to show some cash before leaving. This is where things got interesting. The man obviously didn't have any money; and, sure, he considered the possibility of getting busted again, but he at least wanted one hell of a meal out of it. And now he wasn't getting his hell of a meal, nor a meal of any level of damnation. So he feeling a bit lousy about the whole situation. And what did he do? He decided that, rather than go down gracefully, he was going to go down literally: He got on the floor and started to fake having a seizure right in the middle of the lobby. The best part about the entire scenario was how blatantly phony it was. About halfway through his erratic spasms, another manager decided to give him a soft kick, to which the man replied, ending his seizures all together and taking an authoritative tone, "DON'T YOU KICK ME!" He immediately proceeded to return to his "seizures." One of the managers made a quick sprint for the phone and called the cops, while the other manager tried to persuade the guests to take a seat in the bar to get away from this nutjob. His efforts were in vain, as, and this is one of my favorite parts of this entire story, the guests thought it was hilarious to watch this grown man squirm and cry like a baby. The manager really couldn't argue, as he himself was holding back laughter. Eventually, though, the cops did arrive. Upon seeing the man on the floor, they said, and I quote: "Oh, Paul, get up." The homeless man stood up, went with the police officers, and the managers both burst out into uncontrollable laughter. So that's my most exciting work story to date, and it'll be a tough act to follow. Odds are I'll go for the rest of the summer without getting anything nearly as great as that. As far as Brian-centric stories go, you've now heard the pick of the litter - don't expect anything that entertaining to come out of me until I at least get back to school. Also, and this is my last job related paragraph, my job gives me the single greatest perk of all time: Free Red Lobster cheese bread at all times. I can eat it on the spot, I can grab some in a bag and take it home with me, I can give it to ducks to give them a taste of luxury and a break from that dull normal bread they get all the time; anything you can think of involving Red Lobster cheese bread, I can do. I've actually got about 18 pieces of it sitting on my counter from my shift on Thursday, and it's definitely not getting any more fresh as the days pass. So, you know, if you want bread, just swing by my house. I'm serious here: I have too much bread. If you want some, just ring my doorbell. I'll give you some. It might be kind of stale, but it's really gotta go. It's getting very old. And if you live far away from me, post your mailing address and I will send you some. At this point, I doubt it a few days of shipping will have a huge effect on how stale it most likely is. Next obligatory thing on which I should probably comment: Gee, summer is already more than half-over. Oh dear. I can't say I'm particularly upset or shocked - I don't know how shock could play into this, as I've counted the days of my summer crawl by one by one and the current tally seems about right. More than anything, I'm nearly relieved. Summer's become almost somewhat of a nuisance. Sure, yeah, it's great to be home, see people I haven't seen in a while, and hang out with the old high school crew; but it's also not. Don't get me wrong, I love doing nothing. And I love doing nothing with all of you guys. But, relatively speaking, I've fallen into the belief that I never thought I would: College, even when it's in boring-ass Mt. Pleasant, is more interesting than home life. There are more people, more things to do (and I plan to take more advantage of this next year than the last, as I actually get around to applying to the paper as a reporter. I also might look into the radio station, but we'll see if I have the ambition to take part in more than one activity), and, from a work angle, the classes are slightly more satisfying than working a part-time job that, although I don't entirely loathe, isn't particularly satisfying in any regard. Receiving a generous tip doesn't feel nearly as fulfilling as getting an A and a slew of positive comments on an essay that was pulled together last minute. But that's not to say that summer doesn't have a few more tricks up its sleeve. Free laundry aside, the best summer has to offer is undoubtedly the greatly-anticipated-since-March-when-it-was-announced-God-I've-had-the-tickets-in-my-sock-drawer-for-months Pitchfork music festival. It's going to be absolutely fantastic. Great bands, larger group than the Nate-Brian duo, great city; hell, we don't even have to pay for hotel fees this time, as Nate's old roommate conveniently lives in Chicago and is letting all of us crash at his place. The only real downside I can think of, and this hurts me ever so, is that the Mountain Goats and Destroyer are playing back-to-back sets. Since they're inarguably my two most anticipated acts at the festival, I'm kind of bummed that I'll get a great spot for the Mountain Goats but be forced to settle for a mediocre spot at Destroyer. The dilemma may be enough rip my heart in two - from there, half of my heart would get a good spot at the Mountain Goats and the other half would get in one of the front rows for Destroyer. Well, at least I'll be nice and up close for good ol' John Darnielle, and I think this video adequately sums up why the Mountain Goats will be a must-see. If he starts playing "The Best Ever Death Metal Band in Denton," absolutely nothing, not even the sight of a two-inch Dan Bejar, could dampen my spirits. More on Pitchfork in a couple weeks, when I'm in the state of bittersweet relaxation from having my face thoroughly rocked off for two days straight. To close, I figure I should write on a couple of things I'm sure everybody cares about. I got another haircut recently - partially for work, partially because my hair was at a frustrating stage of middle-length. It's shorter than ever before this time. If you thought the last cut shocked and awed, you aren't even ready for this one. I definitely don't think it looks bad, but I'm not completely satisfied with it. I like a little more length on top - enough to, at the very least, appear the part of disheveled and eccentric, something of which I'm not currently capable. But I suppose it's growing on me: a millimeter or so a day, I imagine. In a couple weeks, I should be moderately pleased, and by school, it will be what I would consider adequate. On the plus side, I get to do something I haven't truly been able to do since junior year of high school: Go through all the exciting stages of hair growth. My hair currently feels like a fuzzy embryo, waiting to fully mature and be raised into a successful mane. It'll give me a good sense of variety throughout the school year, at the very least. Also, I got another pair of sunglasses, finally. My old dollar-store circular rose tinted pair were no longer up to par. They were tainted by scratches, blemishes, and the inherent flaw of blocking very little sunlight, rendering them fairly useless. Now I've got a slightly darker, slightly ritzier (JC Penney quality, everybody!) pair. I'm told I now look like a total beatnick with them on, which is, I suppose, a step up from the smelly hippie status I had with my old pair. Well, that's it. I'm done with this thing for now. I'm going to consider the unruly length of this entry warm-up for what will inevitably be a nearly interminable entry on the Pitchfork festival in a couple of weeks. If you don't believe me, just read my entry from last year; that thing was long, and I'm even more verbose now than I was back then. Is there a character limit on livejournal entries? We'll find out.

I'll admit. Over the past couple of weeks, I started to lose some enthusiasm about summer. The job hunt was going miserably, the weather was either too hot or too rainy, and it didn't seem like I could catch a break anywhere. Well, the largest of my problems - the job - seems to have cleared up a bit. I had an interview with the Madison Heights Red Lobster yesterday to become a server, and I feel it went quite well. I met with the guy who would be my direct manager, and I think he at least kind of liked me. The interview was standard-fare: A few questions about customer service, myself, etc etc. There's apparently some numeric grading system that accompanies the interview, and I have no idea how it could work on something that's entirely short answer, but it doesn't really matter. I was, evidently, a solid enough interviewee to make the manager give me a vote of confidence; he skipped the entire grading system, saying that I did a, and I quote, "very good job and [he] couldn't imagine how I could have failed." So that's a very positive thing. I have one more interview on Monday with the general manager - the head honcho of the Red Lobster, the guy with his name adorned on some fancy fish sign in the front of the restaurant - to, I assume, seal the deal, as long as I don't totally blow it. From there, they should start training me the following week; the previous Thursday being a day to iron out all the paperwork. If I land this job, and I hope I do, I feel it necessary to point out the amount of Benjamins in which I will be rolling: Quite a few. Waiting would be a significantly better job than the shitty minimum wage work I was expecting, and while it's probably going to be a bit more work than, say, some video store job, every day I will have tips as a form of solace. Not to mention that, honestly, I think I would enjoy waiting more than a lot of easier, menial work. All of my charm and charisma, which currently goes toward doing jack shit, will go toward selling delicious dishes of seafood. I also received another response. In a move that could be deemed entirely unnecessary, Jazzy Java, a local coffee shop that just opened on 18 and Rochester, gave me a phone call this morning specifically to tell me that they were not going to hire me. This is also the place that, if I haven't talked to you at all over the past week, had an application that was no more than some one-page personal, informal letter about why I'd like to work at the shop. Anyway, during the phone call, the manager told me that, while I was apparently a promising applicant (I pride myself in my one-page personal, informal letters!), they weren't interested in hiring me because I'd be leaving in the fall. They said it'd take roughly two months to train me in all the intricacies of their coffee shop works, and by the time I'd be fully self-sufficient, it'd be August and I'd be leaving. I guess that's understandable, even though I doubt it'd take two full months to figure out coffee, tea, and gelato, but hey, I still really appreciate the fact that they actually gave me a response, even if they weren't interested in hiring me. It's entirely a psychological thing; whereas every other time I was rejected for a job (and boy, were there a lot of those) seemed like a kick in the crotch while I wasn't looking, this was like a friendly pat on the back with an encouraging, "try again sometime, man!" In fact, they even told me to try again sometime I'd be in town for longer. Not that I can think of a single time I'd be in time for any longer than summer vacation, but hey, they're trying to be supportive. They're at least making a concerted effort to make me feel as if I haven't been kicked in the crotch. There was a Walkmen show last night, which I decided to attend on a whim. I wasn't entirely sure about going to the show - between that, Dungen, and Pitchfork, it would almost seem as if I was spending too much money on concerts. Money that, and this is assuming my current unemployed status, I don't have. But hey, I had just made fifty bucks helping Mrs. Racklyeft move stuff and tear out carpet, and it's not like I spend money on much else these days. Sure, I should be spending my money on better, more responsible things; but being the irresponsible, carefree teenager I am, "should" has no place in my vocabulary. I saw The Walkmen last night, and it was awesome. More within: Let me start by saying that I'm very, very lucky that I'm alive right now. And no, this isn't some lame, cheap shot at Detroit being a total hellhole; this is an entirely reasonable remark about the state of the weather during our drive to the show. Before we entered the storm, I made the remark to Cory that it looked like the clouds surrounding Hyrule Castle after Ganon took over in Ocarina of Time. And they were, indeed, very intimidating and scary-looking; not that we could see them for long, of course. The second we entered the storm, the windshield suddenly became overtaken by the water of something in between a monsoon and a Biblical flood. We couldn't drive more than a couple minutes before giving up, pulling over under some tunnel, and being amazed that the rain was actually blowing in the tunnel in amounts that were still slightly blinding. Between that, the crash of thunder, and the flash of lightning, I definitely considered the possibility of dying; or, at the very least, being cripplingly wounded. But eventually the rain did let up, and our bodies were completely in tact. After a bit of additional stumbling thanks to a shoddy map from the ticketmaster website, (I suppose it's fair - we bought tickets at the door instead of online, so ticketmaster didn't get to fuck us over in service fees. Getting us lost for a half an hour was the least they could do.) we arrived at St. Andrews' Hall. "Who knows what that beat is?" This was the first thing I heard when I walked into the place. Upon further investigation, the beat was a slowed down version of that from "Funkytown", and there was some crazy-looking fat guy with a moustache on the stage. This man will be referred to, from this point on, as Crazy Fucker. This is the most fitting label I can imagine for this man - not just because he was maniacal (which he was), and not just because I don't actually know his name, but because he wanted to fuck everything. Not in the sexual sense, of course; but he told people who like to roller blade to fuck off, he told polar bears to fuck off, and I'm struggling to think of something he didn't, at some point, tell to fuck off. His lyrics were literally his monologue put to chords, with lines such as "The weather's real nice / too bad we're all going to die soon." And then there was that whole thing about baby seals being happy about global warming, because it would kill polar bears, the natual hunter of baby seals. I suppose that's a good way to look at it, but, as he was quick to remind us, too bad we're all going to die soon. The second opener was much closer to what I expected out of an opener for the Walkmen. They were fairly good, straightforward indie rock, almost like some kind of Walkmen-lite. It was a fitting warm-up for the Walkmen. After the jarring, yet entertaining, experience of Crazy Fucker, I needed something to get me back into the groove of toe-tapping and head-nodding, which these guys did quite well. They met my criteria for a good opener: An enjoyable way to pass the time. And they did get me in the mood for The Walkmen. The Walkmen themselves were absolutely fantastic. It never struck me just how much the singer fuckin' wails during his songs. It was somewhere along the third time I saw the veins popping in his neck during "The Rat" that I realized I was in for a spectacular show. It wasn't just some lame, scream-o scream either; this man possessed the sheer vocal power to turn that scream into actual pitches, while still maintaining all of the energy that comes with a killer scream. He also had the rock and roll microphone stagger down to a science; he knew just how far he could tip that microphone stand without having it fall into the audience. It's commendable that he was able to keep this level of energy throughout the entire show. I remember, slightly before the show, the set-up crew brought out a fan and tilted it toward the audience, then tilted it toward only the band. I was kind of bummed about that, but after seeing just how much vocal strain the singer puts himself through, I'm completely understanding. I'm not overly familiar with many specific Walkmen songs - most of the times I listen to them I just let one of their album play through and call it that, never really noting many song names - but one track off the new album, "Louisiana," I was slightly worried about. See, "Louisiana," is a great song, but there is one thing that seperates it from the rest of the Walkmen's catalog: It has a horn line. And the horn line, really, is an integral part of the song. When they began strumming the opening chords, I was a little worried - I didn't see a single trumpet in sight. And this anxiety lasted for a good minute of the song, until I saw the guitarist step aside, revealing a trumpet resting on one of the amps. I immediately felt a feeling of catharsis, as the guitarist played the horn line that I love oh so much. We also got to meet the group after the show for a bit. As it turns out, the singer is Cory's ex-drumline-member's cousin, so we had the connections. We didn't really talk for long, though. While he didn't sound tired throughout any of the songs, the singer was totally hoarse after the show. I guess it's fair - he is human, afterall. And no human could look like his neck is about to explode for nearly an hour without some sort of exhaustion. Great show, and the singer seemed like a cool enough dude. This isn't the end of my concert-going, though. Next Monday I'm seeing Swedish rockers and prettiest band on the planet, Dungen. They turned me down on the basis of availability based solely on that section, despite my actual schedule being entirely open. That application was deceptive as hell, and, Panera, I don't approve of your dirty hiring tricks. So, now, where's this leave me? I'm not entirely sure. I'm now attempting to follow up on the Einstein Bros. application I dropped off over spring break, which will hopefully turn up an actual result. I called them up earlier today, and they said that they were working on sifting through the applications, and that they were waiting for some of their people to leave for the summer before hiring a new staff.
