But I'd prefer not to, because when it comes to shitty part-time jobs, I'd rather be on the less-shitty end of the spectrum - a job that will, if one were to continue this fecal analogy for much longer than would be considered reasonable, be more of a clean, solid stool than horrific, bloody diarrhea. But that's not to say my summer hasn't had some interesting elements. I've finally been catching up on the huge backlog of games I've been meaning to play. The first on my list, and probably the biggest as it's been on this backlog for over five years, was Ocarina of Time. Yes, the Zelda game. Yes, the game that's widely considered to be one of the finest pieces of digital software ever made. And yes, the game that I'd never completed. But now the overwhelming burden of shame that comes with never having completed Ocarina of Time is lifted. Now, if I'm ever around anybody that brings up the topic of this game and how great it is, I no longer have to sheepishly mumble, "I never finished it" - I can now say, with complete confidence, "yeah, I agree." The next game on my list: Paper Mario 2. It's lots of fun so far, and it's got pretty much all of the charm and originality I remember from the original. So that's something to do to kill the time - something to do while lounging in my bathrobe. But, by far, the boldest and most adventurous aspect of my summer has to be my newfound cereal lifestyle. I'll admit, Central had me spoiled when it comes to cereal. After experiencing the sheer ecstasy of a cereal bar - the terrific joy of no less than 16 selections, spanning from Kellog to General Mills, at any given time of the day - it was hard to go back to my regular diet of either nothing or Pop-Tarts. So I've been keeping the cupboard well-stocked, and not only that, but I've found that the aisles of Kroger have an even more fantastic selection than CMU. I've had some legitimately exotic breakfasts thanks to my trips to Kroger, and I'd like to share some of the best with you: Peanut Butter Toast Crunch: Let me get this out of the way first: I've been interested in this cereal for nearly six months now, ever since I saw it in the aisles of Meijer with (I believe) Cory and Alesa. It does seem like a match made in heaven - the sweet goodness of Cinnamon Toast Crunch combined with the creamy deliciousness of, well, anything with peanut butter in it. After months of anticipation, did the cereal live up to the hype? I regret to say it did not. That's not to say it's bad, persay, but not quite a match made in heaven. It's more of a match made outside of the pearly gates that wasn't quite up to St. Peter's snuff - turned down and forced to exist in cereal limbo with other unsuccessful but bold journeys into cereal combinations. Still, though, I'd say it's worth a shot, but it doesn't dethrone Peanut Butter Captain Crunch as the current leader in peanut butter cereal. Berry Lucky Charms: Totally Boo Berry, right?! Well, assuming you know what Boo Berry is - Boo Berry is a delicious cereal that exists only in the rarest of locations. It combines the sweet berry goodness of a fruity cereal and enhances it with tasty marshmallows. I've had Boo Berry on a couple of previous occasions, and I definitely enjoyed it. But my inexperience with my cereal didn't allow me to fully see its weakness, which became very apparant after my second day of eating it for breakfast - it's just not very filling. It's tasty, it's sweet, but it just can't fill me up as well as, say, Frosted Mini-Wheats. A tasty mid-day treat, yes, but a breakfast? Hardly. And not only that, but I think General Mills downed the marshmallow:cereal-piece ratio, and that's just not cool. Other than that, I've pretty much just stuck to the norms: Frosted Mini-Wheats, Honey Nut Cheerios, etc. But even the dullest cereal can be made exciting when going through my standard cereal restocking process. I'm quite the happening sight at Kroger, falling into probably at least a dozen college slacker stereotypes. I typically purchase three fresh boxes along with a new gallon of milk (assuming my dad hasn't restocked that recently), and carts are for suckers, so I just try to carry everything in my hands. So there I am, shaggy hair, slightly wrinkled button-down shirt, jeans, carrying three boxes of cereal underneath one arm and a gallon of milk in the other hand. An impeccable image of college slackerdom roaming the aisles of Kroger - I highly encourage all of you to be on the lookout for me next time you're in the area. You may just get to experience one of the greatest sights of your life. All I ask of you, when you set eyes upon my unkempt self, is to realize just how much effort was required for me to get out of my bathrobe.

Today's been fantastic. Despite having three classes, I've managed to not go to any of them, and I don't need to feel any sort of guilt for skipping. I feel it was justified, anyway. The elusive Chris Witt, man of many plans every weekend I am in town, was at Central for the morning, and what kind of person would I be if I selfishly chose to learn about ancient history and sign language instead of visiting him the one chance I had? I made the right decision. Admittedly, it wasn't easy to turn my back on three hours of learning, but what can I say? I'm just a great friend. And not only that, but my journalism class, my third class on Tuesday, was canceled due to an out of class assignment that is, upon reading the requirements, very, very easy. I have to observe people's habits with mass media, and write, in a one-page credit/no-credit paper, their uses and gratifications with the piece of media. It's also not due until Thursday, so not only is it an easy assignment, but I get the opportunity to procrastinate as well. However, today, even in its terrific abandon of all classes, can't hold a candle to the wild and crazy weekend that was Easter weekend. First, and the topic that I feel most obligated to write on, was that I did officially go through with the hair cut. In a move that certainly sacrificed a bit of my manliness, I opted to go with a fancy salon, via Cory's recommendation (yes, that does make this even more effeminate). But I feel the end result was worth it - the general consensus, from what I can tell, is that the hair cut was a very, very good decision. And it's most certainly easier to maintain - gone are the days of conditioning for a good five minutes! Now, my hair only requires a couple of minutes to look its best! And I've also got this ritzy finishing cream, which helps keep it from getting massively frizzy and poofy. It's all very professional, let me say. The weekend did, however, take a turn for the worst on the trip to Kalamazoo to see Vanderslice on Easter. We encountered some really, really rough traffic - I believe we may have gone four or five miles in one hour. What really got me, though, wasn't the simple fact that there was bad traffic, but rather the cause; as it turns out, the traffic back-up was completely unnecessary. It was caused, primarily, by the right lane ending. Now, I'm sure most of you are aware on my stance toward those who ride the lane to its very end, those who choose to ignore the multiple signs indicating the lane's imminent end. I'm not a big fan of them - their selfish douchebaggery is the cause of the very traffic they are trying to avoid. It's all very circular, actually. If we didn't have people driving the lane to its end, there would be no traffic; but if we didn't have any traffic, there wouldn't be any people driving the lane to its end. So, obviously, somebody needed to let these people know the error of their ways - to let them know that, if we all work together, we can stop this vicious cycle! The only true solution in this case would have been the Douche, but it was too dark and the odds of the drivers looking at the window, squinting, and possibly making out the letters "D-O-U-C-H-E" in those final hours of twilight were slim. So I had to be a bit more resourceful. I noticed that many of them were cruising with their windows down. A fact that, if combined with open windows on my car, could allow me to convey a simple message to them. I've been told that I'm loud, I've been told that I can have a very powerful, resonating voice - I didn't understand why I have this voice until that fateful evening. It was this instance that I feel God, who gave me such a powerful, loud voice, intended me to work to change the world for the better and stop this heinous douchebaggery. I really, truly feel that I was put on this Earth to stop people driving down a closing lane to the very end, that it is my one true purpose in life; and I feel that night may have been my test. At every car that drove by, I yelled a message, although ridden with profanity, that offered a better world for everybody; a world where traffic could, at times, break twenty miles an hour. Combined with the Douche sign, courteously held up by one of the other members of my car (who were also committed to creating a utopian driving society), I feel I may have changed lives for the better. One lady, who noticed me in between puffs of her cigeratte, did take my offering - she changed lanes and entered the very comfortable gap I created in between me and the nearest car. And even if I've only affected that one person, at least I've done something. Maybe she will spread the glorious message. Who knows? Someday, we may never have to deal with douchebags in traffic zones. But the payoff for the traffic - the John Vanderslice show - was more than well-worth waiting over an hour in traffic. I was a bit worried that we were going to get there late, especially considering that we were pushing a good half an hour after the doors opened when we picked up Peter from his dorm, but it all worked out okay. The show was incredibly small, moreso than any other small venue show I've attended - there were maybe about fifty or so members in the entire audience. So, my main concern, which was being stuck in a crappy spot in the back of the bar, wasn't even an issue. The back of the crowd didn't extend very far past the stage, and we actually managed to land really great spots, because we managed to show up before the opener ended. Once people got out of the crowd after the opener to grab another beer or use the bathroom, we were able to be in the second and third row without a problem. Vanderslice's performance was everything I expected it to be. He's a very talented man, gifted with one of my favorite voices in all of music. He managed to cover most of the songs I wanted to see live, and, despite a couple of issues with the Moog (ultra 80's keyboard, for those not in the know), he performed them very, very well. He had a nice balance between his more powerful, active songs, which filled the room with energy (although not quite as much as, say, an Of Montreal show. Except for that guy next to me who was really getting into it - he definitely was filled to the brim with energy), and his more delicate songs, which were absolutely beautiful. Even though the show itself was great, it wasn't the real stand-out point of the night. While I wouldn't say Vanderslice was the best show I've been to, it would certainly pass as the best after-show. As I said earlier, the crowd was incredibly small during the show, which created a great personal atmosphere throughout the entire thing. But after the show, the crowd thinned out even more, leaving us, about ten or twenty other people, and Vanderslice. Considering that, hey, I love his music and I've heard he's a great guy, I figured it couldn't hurt to talk to him for a bit. So, after I caved into the terrific CD + t-shirt for $20 deal, we went up to chat for a bit. We talked for probably about a good five-ten minutes, and from that I can confirm one thing: John Vanderslice is indeed one of the nicest, coolest people on the planet. I find it interesting that many people associate independent songwriters, their fans, and this type of show with high levels of pretentiousness, but really, it's anything but, and Vanderslice is probably the strongest example to dispell that stupid rumor. John is the anti-thesis of pretentiousness; I couldn't imagine him ever, ever snubbing a fan. We talked about all the things in life that matter - you know, what it's like to be on tour, what the guys from Death Cab are like (he toured Europe with them before his US leg), what was his favorite country of all of the ones in Europe. And we also talked about the Pitchfork festival, which was, unfortunately, a bit of a sour note. Vanderslice regretted to inform us that, despite his best efforts, Pitchfork turned him down for the festival. Man, how lame is that? We told him that we thought it was everybit as much of a drag as he did. I think the coolest part of the conversation, though, was that while we were talking about the tour, Cory brought up the possibility of him coming to Mt. Pleasant, and he, surprisingly, wasn't opposed to the idea. He actually kind of liked it - apparently, he likes doing smaller colleges. He's even doing some even smaller, no-name universities during this tour, and he said that we should just email his booking agent sometime next fall to try to get him for a show. Now, as somebody who's considering getting involved with the radio station, I couldn't imagine anything cooler than having John Vanderslice on campus. He'd certainly be leaps and bounds ahead of any musical act we've had this semester, and it might even earn him a few new fans. And after meeting him, it's impossible to hope for anything but great success for the man. He's just so damn, well, nice. And it's not fake, ridiculously-bubbly nice either; it's just the right mix of quirky and kind that makes it seem really, truly genuine. If that's not enough to convince you of the quality of his character, he also brought in Easter cookies and Peeps for the audience. I mean, come on. Do I even have to say anything else? I'll just close with one last thing that I feel best summarizes the John Vanderslice experience: If he does come on campus, I totally want to grab lunch with him. And as much as I'd love to go on about how terrific Vanderslice is as both a musician and a person, I've gotta get out of here. Scrubs is on!

God, I can't believe it's already Spring. It just seems like yesterday I was jubilantly celebrating the Winter Solstice, and now we're already at the start of new season. Not that I'm complaining by any means; I'm perfectly okay with not needing both a sweater and full length wool jacket to get to the point where I maintain feeling in all portions of my body. I feel Spring got off to a fairly decent start. The weather could have been slightly less brisk, but it was nothing my cheap lightweight jacket couldn't handle. The moderately fine spring weather got me thinking more than usual - thinking to the extent that I need not one, not two, not... actually, I'm not sure how many I'll need, but more than one livejournal cut. Step back. I managed to complete my history essay last night by two o'clock, which I feel is a major accomplishment, considering I knew next to jack shit going into it. I feel that, despite waiting until the last minute to start it, I was fairly responsible. I looked over the syllabus before starting the essay, just to make sure I wasn't missing anything, and it had some book listed next to "see also:". Now, in a desperate act to appear intelligent and prepared, I decided to check out this book and skim it for basic information. Well, surprisingly, it was incredibly helpful, and I managed to use a pretty decent amount of information from it throughout the essay. But more importantly, it gives me a second source on the bibliography page, and that just screams "professional historian". If he's not sold on my essay by the conclusion paragraph, that expansive bibliography page will give me the extra kick I need. I'm not going to lie - reading fancy, smarmy history books is a borderline guilty pleasure of mine. I developed a taste for the stuff last semester with my French Revolution book, which was written by an author who explicitly stated at the start of the book that all other historians are full of shit and their theories on the French Revolution are for chumps and chumps alone. My current book lacks much of this cocky, self-assured nature; it's too objective, often looking at history itself as opposed to calling other historians dinks. But the book I checked out last night made up for everything. I don't think he went a single paragraph without writing some variation of the sentence, "this is what other historians believe and hahahaha what the hell how can they believe this shit?" And, I'll admit, their overly eloquent writing style also strikes a certain chord with me. I admire a writer who in an average sentence has triple the number of colons in the human body, mixed in between a blitzkrieg of commas. Historians are, without a doubt, the cockiest fuckers on the planet. It makes me want to drop journalism, broadcasting, or whatever I feel like majoring in two weeks from now and study pure history. Not even teaching - a pure, scholarly job in history. The kind of job where the only practical application is an interview for The History Channel. I want to do this just because I'd absolutely love to be invited to one of these history conferences I've heard so much about. Not because I'd like to debate with these guys; no, rather, I'd be perfectly satisfied simply being able to watch. I'm entirely convinced that the guy who wrote my French Revolution book would start throwing some punches if he had a couple drinks in him and somebody said economic factors were the primary cause of the Revolution, and I'll bet that Ancient Greek historian I read last night would start droppin' some killer zings like, "oh yeah? yo momma held isonomia (equality by political rights) in the highest regard - it's the only way she could love you!" It would be fantastic. And I all I would have to do is sit back and watch. Anyway, that's enough about historians. I think one of my new life goals is to write a history on historians. I'm sure it's been done - in fact, our school has a class entirely devoted to the craft of history - but what the hell do those other guys know? Every other history on historians is wrong except for this one. I haven't even written it yet, but I understand that, as a historian of historians, I need the mindset of a historian: in order for this to be an accurate account, I need to possess the mind-boggling self-righteousness of a historian: this is why I will prevail: also, my sentences need more colons. Moving on. I recently downloaded the Man Man album, Six Demon Bag. It's a pretty good and very unique album, but that's beyond the point. The point is that this band plays into every possible image that could lure me to listen to them. First off, their name is Man Man - that alone was awesome enough to get me to consider searching OiNK for a copy. But once You Ain't No Picasso posted an image of the band, I was instantly sold. I think the moustache-aviator combo speaks for itself: That is one of the best handlebar moustaches I've seen since the glory days of the 70's. The hair perfectly compliments the aviators, and his voice is every bit as gravelly and manly as you'd expect. If you're interested in hearing a sample, you know who to IM. Working off this, I've created the image of the ideal man in my head. He is a combination of all of the best I've seen among my gender, rolled into one irresistible-to-the-ladies superman: 1. The moustache of Honus (the frontman; fuck, just look at that name, too!) of Man Man. 2. The hair of Gustav Ejstes of Dungen. 3. The voice of Will Arnet. Now, I've yet to hire a professional artist to make a temporary mock-up of my superman, but I think it's safe to say that no female within a ten mile radius could resist him. Also, last but most certainly not least, I'm considering getting a haircut sometime soon. Nothing major, don't worry. It would be a trim at most. My current problem is that, as of now, my goal of a Gustav-level mane (see above) is hindered by my hair's proportions. It's too short in the front and too long in the back - not quite business in the front, party in the back level, but you get my point. It needs to be shaped. I'm not entirely sure what I'll do with it yet, but I just figured I should give you guys a heads-up. Give adequate time to let it sink in. By the way, if you've managed to read through all this entry, I think I might love you.

Two weeks ago I was going through a rough time. It was midterm season, and I had two midterms back to back, neither of which I was ready for: History and Sign Language. Preparation be damned - I didn't read three chapters of the "required" reading for history and I hadn't touched my sign language book all semester. So, needless to say, exam day was interesting. But I had managed to complete the exams with enough competency to be at the level where I wasn't entirely dreading seeing the results after break. Well, today was that day I wasn't entirely dreading. And there wasn't really a need to entirely dread it! In fact, the first of my exams, history, actually went quite well! I managed to pull a solid A on the exam. But not only did I pull the A, I pulled the exact amount of point necessary to receive an A, meaning that I did just the right amount of reading and studying. Any more would have been excessive, any less would have put me at the frustrating A- mark; I was able to possess just the right amount of knowledge to give my professor, if I recall correctly, a slight look of shock when he saw that one of the A's belonged to the kid who always came to class fifteen minutes late because he was too lazy to wake up with ample time to both shower and eat lunch before class. And not only that, but I pulled one of the proudest moments in my short answer BS-ing history. I completely missed the point on one of the questions, going on some entirely unrelated tangent. But here's the catch: My tangent technically had a little truth behind it, and my professor thought it was interesting, so he gave me a 7/10 on that part of the exam. In your face, knowing correct answers. But the day wouldn't have been complete without a little reason to dread it. All of my dreading came to a climax when I received my sign language exam grade. 78%. Okay, that's not that terrible, all things considered. But my professor is one of those people who makes a chart of the grade spectrum on the board, and guess who was the little slash mark right at the bottom? That's right, I was. I managed to score below every single other person in the class. But, in my defense, the front page of the exam is kind of a crock of shit. I nailed everything except for the direct to English translations, and that's because I only know the basic gist of the signs, not their direct English counterparts. So I was losing points on stuff like writing the word "warm" instead of "hot". That was kind of a drag. Also, I mean, the class only has fourteen people, so I'm going to put a positive spin on all of this: The other thirteen students did very well. Way to go, rest of the class! I knew you had it in you! So, yeah. Kind of a mixed bag. But on the plus side, I switched shampoo and conditioners. I'm now totally using chick hair care products, but it's the only way I can get the shine and bounce I so desperately need. So, regardless of the exam, one thing was always an A+: My hair while receiving the grade.

Well, here I am. Nearing the end of my first college spring break. Many other college students plan massive road trips across the country, fly out to exotic locales, or get completely shit-faced every night; my spring break consisted of none of these. But I'd put my break up against theirs any day of the week. I guess it's appropriate to start at the beginning. The car ride home. Fairly run-of-the-mill, solid weather, a nice average of 80+ mph on the highway. We did, however, have more luggage than planned, but it was nothing we couldn't handle. Being the professional crammers we are, we managed to fit Ashley's unsuspected numerous bags of crap in the car with minimal rear view window blockage. The weekend was nice and simple. Nate, Dan, and the rest of the U of M people were at the end of their break, giving us overlapping weekends. This allowed us to do the usual hanging out that we haven't done in a while; this translating to, of course, watching a number of movies Cory's house, including a completely ridiculous Chuck Norris film made even better by the completely ridiculous time of viewing at 1 in the morning. I don't even understand the villain's motive for blowing shit up, nor do I understand Chuck Norris's incentive for blowing them up, but I suppose that's beyond the point - that point being, of course, that shit blew up. Shit blowing up doesn't need an explanation, there should never be a "how?" or "why?" There should only be an "awesome!" The end of the weekend was where my true journey began. Sunday and Monday are what I like to refer to as the workin' man phase. Over those two days, I put more effort into finding a job for the summer than I ever have. Tuesday brought back my renegade, wild side you saw last entry with the theft of Family Video's phonebook. But I couldn't let that take down my entire break; no, the best was yet to come. The initiation of Concert Season: Spring '06: The double-header of Ted Leo & The Pharmacists and Of Montreal in the fine city of Ann Arbor. By the way, when I say "fine", I'm not referring to city quality - I'm referring to how incredibly easy it is to get fined for a parking ticket, as half of the parking structures have the most ridiculous set of rules I've ever seen. First, let me say what Cory and I eventually had to settle on, and keep in mind that this was the best option. We parked in a student lot that was free parking from 6 PM to 6 AM, then after Ted Leo we moved our car to an adjoining pre-pay visitor lot, where we had to pay 40 cents per half hour over a timespan of 16 hours. Then, the next day, we had to move our car back to the free student lot between 6 and 6:30 PM to avoid getting ticketed at the pre-pay lot. We then left Ann Arbor immediately after Of Montreal to avoid paying for the pre-pay lot again. I don't even want to try to explain some of the parking lots we saw. A number of them were 40 cents per half hour all day, including our pre-pay lot, but that was way, way, way too much for us to pay, so we're just glad we managed to work around it for a good portion of our time. Also, even some of the 40 cents per half hour lots had their own ridiculous rules, a number of which involved the towing of cars, something we certainly did not want to have a part of. Weekend Ann Arbor is much, much better than weekday Ann Arbor. Weekday Ann Arbor is about as welcoming to visitors as Athens is to their alumni. Anyway, the shows! Wow... what a quality couple of evenings. In a way, I train for concerts. Rock concerts have long been the only practical application for long hair, so all the shampooing, conditioning, and brushing I've done since late October has all been a build-up to these two shows, where I would finally put that hair in action. Fortunately, both Ted Leo and Of Montreal gave me plenty of reason to whip that hair around, giving me two solid nights of rocking. I'm going to cut this part because I know that, of all the uninteresting things I write about, concert reviews are by and far the least interesting. Let me preface everything about these two shows by saying that the night before I left Ann Arbor I developed a killer sore throat. This is very, very bad for concerts, which, more often than not, involve lots and lots of screaming. So, uh, I was kind of bummed about that. But no pain, no gain, right? I would just have to be selective with my "woo"s, "yeah"s, and other shouts of encouragement, as I could only burn through so many. So here we go, Wednesday night, the car was parked, and it was time for... Ted Leo and the Pharmacists: This was also, as far as I'm concerned, the Central Michigan University indie kids music festival. Nearly everybody that I'm aware of with similar tastes in music to mine was there, including Ashleigh, Brooke, and Audrey, all with their own groups of people. So it was nice to run into these people and, for a fleeting moment, feel like I was popular around CMU. But enough about the social aspect! I didn't pay fourteen dollars to mill around with people, I payed it to see Ted Leo... and because Ticketmaster, my only choice for getting tickets, charged an insane amount in service fees... but mostly to see Ted Leo! The openers were pretty alright, with the first band, some Spanish dude and his drummer, playing some of the loudest shit I've ever heard. It was the kind of stuff that makes The Flaming Lips circa 1980's look like conservative song-writers. It was borderline deafening, with every randomly placed guitar strum feeling like this man had it out for my eardrums. To give you an example, there was a point mid-way through the set when the Spainard played a recorder, smacking his guitar strings with said recorder in between squeaks. This was somehow not shocking. Also, judging by some of the lyrics, the only one I was able to make out being "SMELL THE EYE!!!!", I'm fairly sure this music was meant to be experienced with acid. Or at least pot. Sober as I was, it was just painful. The second band was okay. I wasn't able to quite make out their name - every time the singer said their name it sounded like she was just mumbling something incoherent - but I suppose that's fitting. Their music wasn't really memorable in any way, shape, or form. But what was memorable was this drunk dude who decided to charge up mid-set and try to make the place into a mash pit. Let me explain something for you, in case you didn't know: The crowd that goes to see Ted Leo is, for the most part, not the type of people who enjoy mashing. Therefore, when this drunk man came stumbling up through the crowd and started shit, the crowd wasn't too enthusiastic with him. But his friend was! That's right, this man had a friend, equally drunk and obnoxious as he. Together, they rammed into people and looked very out of place, as everybody around him was giving glaring death-stares. Fortunately, the second opener was done after a couple of songs with the two of them, and, being drunk as they were, they had to badly take a pee. It was at this point that everybody within a ten person radius of me banded together and promised each other to never, ever, under any circumstance, let either of them back through. We were to be a wall. Our wall, fortunately, worked. We didn't see either of them for the rest of the night, which made Ted Leo a much, much more enjoyable show. Ted Leo's a good guy. He puts on a good show. His music is energetic, upbeat, and catchy. He's also a real charmer, talking about topics ranging from Project Runway to how much he hates certain idioms. In fact, one of the members of the audience baked cupcakes for him and the two other members in his band, which is a clear sign of this man's popularity. If I ever get to the point where strangers will make me cupcakes, I'll know I've made it in life. Also, the bassist had some killer hair. Probably some of the best band hair I've seen since I first set eyes on Dungen. And the drummer had a killer beard, looking like Obi-Wan Kenobi crossed with Jesus. So, even though they didn't have nearly the stage presence of Ted Leo himself, the Pharmacists were at the very least an interesting looking batch of fellows. All in all, a very good show. I enjoyed the songs, banter, and hair. Afterward, we went out to Jimmy John's with Ashleigh and her group of people, where I attempted to be a part of conversation despite my throat burning with the fire of a hundred suns and my vocal chords feeling like they were punching each other. But, I mean, I did the best I could. So my voice was pretty shot. But I had enough left to run on, I could manage to recover enough for Thursday's show... Of Montreal: I'm not sure if everybody who could possibly be reading this is familiar with Of Montreal. I think everybody is; I've certainly brought them up before. I've described them as ultra-sugary, super-sweet with a tint of psychedelic pop music. I don't think that descriptor is enough to describe an Of Montreal live show. What they do live is, simply put, the musical equivalent of ingesting two dozen pixie sticks. In fact, I'm entirely convinced that the notes played in every single one of their songs has the same effect on the brain as the chemicals in sugar. I should conduct a study one of these days. I'm aware of a certain chunk of older, conservative members of our society concerned about music demoralizing our youth; Of Montreal stands as a beacon of light in a sea of reprobates. Of Montreal is a classy act. Before the show began, the members of the group all set up on stage, sans one: The frontman, Kevin Barnes. The band then began to play the wedding march, as Kevin, wearing a wedding dress, entered the building. Once he completed this beautiful march, he stepped up to the mic to explain himself. You see, Of Montreal is a bunch of old-fashioned gals, and they would like to make sweet love to us, the audience, this evening, but we'd need to get married first. So, to solve this problem, he asked us if we'd take his hand in marriage - we, of course, enthusiastically yelled out "I do!!" Kevin put a ring on the finger of a lucky member of the front row, slipped into something more comfortable, and the show began. So there you go! Of Montreal is a firm supporter of abstinence and a prime role-model for today's youth! The music was, as previously mentioned, a sugar rush. Every song equally as infectious as the last, it was hard to find a single head in the crowd not at the very least nodding; I, along with many others, went far beyond the simple head nod. I'm not much of a dancer, but much like after consuming a large quantity of sugar, it was hard to stand still. And singing along whenever possible was also imperative. It completely annihilated whatever was left of my voice, but I was able to, with great effort, make pitches that kind of matched with Kevin's. It was totally worth it. But the real highlight of evening came not from Of Montreal's songs, but from a certain classic written by a small group by the name of Europe: The Final Countdown. That's right, Of Montreal did a cover of The Final Countdown. Kind of. Unfortunately, they didn't have the whole song down, but they were able to play enough of the opening riff to give the crowd a decent sample. This was enough to be a realization of one my life-long dreams: To be able to headbang to The Final Countdown performed live. The Final Countdown intro led into another one of their addictive pop tunes, but I didn't care; Kevin Barnes and his motley crew of musicians had already made one of my dreams come true, how could this night get any better? Well, I'll tell you. During the second song of their encore, The Repudiated Immortals, during one of the times he sang the lyric, "And I'll take care of you if you take care of me," Kevin looked and pointed directly at me. Sure, it could have been the person to the left of me, it could have been the person to the right of me; fuck, it could have even been Nate. But I keep replaying that exact moment in my mind, trailing the exact path of the his index finger, and it HAD to have been pointing toward me. Plus, I could see it in his eyes as I looked back at him. I, of course, acknowledged his offer and even slightly pointed back, because how could I expect him to take care of me if I didn't take care of him? And, to top off the fantastic night, I bought an awesome Of Montreal t-shirt. It's bright green, a color I feel has been sorely missing from my wardrobe. So next on my concert list is Destroyer on Friday, March 24th. Currently, none of you jerks have expressed interest in going with me. So look alive, people! I promise you it will be a good time! Maybe you won't get married, maybe you won't hear The Final Countdown; but I guarantee you'll leave, at the very least, satisfied. And now, here I am, today, the start of Friday. I've still got one more weekend of break left. I'm sure the best has come and gone, but I'm still up for anything this weekend. I just have to warn you: If you're expecting me to "woo" or yell any form of encouragement, you're out of luck.

Scroll down to my last real entry, a couple entries down. Go ahead, take a look at it. That entry was written by a very different man than the one writing this. I've changed over the final week of February. Changed in ways that you may not be able to comprehend. I've become a wanted man. That's right, I've had a little run in with Johnny Law. Last Saturday, Cory, Ashleigh, and myself went to Family Video to rent a movie, hoping to escape the complete drabness of Mt. Pleasant for, at the very least, 90 minutes. We got that temporary escape, but we also got much more: I can only assume that, by now, there are warrants out for our arrests. See, we wanted to get The Weather Man, but Family Video only had a full screen version. As anybody with any knowledge of film could tell you, this is absolutely disastrous - we owed it to the movie's director of cinematography to check the other video stores for a wide screen version. Of course, I wasn't about to just drive to the other local video stores; no, that would be far too fuel inefficient. The best way to check with the other video stores would, obviously, be the phone. I had my cell phone ready to go, but I needed the numbers to other stores. Fortunately, Family Video had a phone book at their front desk for just such an occasion. I called Blockbuster and Videoland, and both turned up nothing. We were forced to settle on the full screen version. Feeling cold, tired, and defeated, I grudgingly paid the clerk $2.50 to have the full screen version for a night. I took my movie and walked out. Cory and Ashleigh followed. When we got in my car, Ashleigh asked where I had gotten that phonebook. I told her I got it from the front desk. She then held up the phone book, which she had, unknowingly, stolen. My heart began to race. There was no way they'd believe our story if we took it back! There's no way we'd "accidentally" walk out with their phonebook! They'd have the police on us in no time! I had no choice: I had to drive! It was our only hope! And now, the illegitimate phone book rests on a shelf in Cory's room. It is not marked by any Family Video labels, so I can only hope that they cannot trace the crime back to us. But who knows? If I don't update over the next month, you'll know where I am. I've also become an actor. For Brooke's directing class, she needed actors for this short scene she has to produce as a project. She asked me for help, and I, as somebody with absolutely, positively nothing to do at this place, obliged. So, as of today, I am a struggling film writer from LA. What is going on, man?!" This is all, obviously, part of my lifelong dream to become Ashton Kutcher. I'm gunning for an MTV show by fall 2007. I've become a knowledgeable historian on Ancient Greece up to the Pelopennesian War. Well, moderately knowledgeable, anyway; the kind of knowledgeable that could, hopefully, answer three of five short answer questions on the topic. The risky part here is that I still haven't read four of the "required" chapters for the class. I mean, I'm in a much better position than I was last entry (I've read seven of the chapters, putting me at where I should've been in early February), but it's still not entirely complete. But I'm a risk-taker. I think that, playing the odds, I'll have read enough to nail three of the questions. And even if it's not on something I've read, I still have my lecture notes to fall back on, which will hopefully fuel me with enough BS to complete the exam. So look at me now. Criminal, actor, historian. A week and a half ago, I never would've saw myself in the position I am today. My life is moving at a mile a minute. It was my freshman gym teacher Mr. Wylde who said, "the body is like a car." Working off that analogy, I should be running of gas any time soon. A mile a minute? That's 720 miles a day! There's no way my body has that kind of mileage! Good thing that in a couple of days I have spring break, where I'll have a full week to refuel. However, gas isn't cheap. And my life is probably an automatic, not a manual, so I mean, I might only be able to afford 3/4 of a tank. Or maybe only 1/2. Actually, forget this. That was the worst analogy ever. Fuck you, Mr. Wylde. Anyway, spring break is going to rule. I'm going to two fantastic concerts, which will open up my first concert season of 2006. Here's a full list of shows I'm considering attending. This is mostly for my reference, but if you feel like accompanying me to any of them, feel free to let me know. Ted Leo and the Pharmacists - Wed, March 8 - Ann Arbor Of Montreal - Thurs, March 9 - Ann Arbor Destroyer - Fri, March 24 - Ann Arbor John Vanderslice - Sun, April 16 - Kalamazoo Built to Spill - Thurs, April 27 - Detroit This list may shrink depending on ticket prices and class conditions for days following, but this is, by my knowledge, a comprehensive list of all the good bands coming through Michigan, sans larger, more expensive shows. If you think I'm missing anything, be sure to tell me. Well, that's all I've got for tonight. I wish I could promise to tell you how the concerts go, but with the way my life is going, who knows where I'll be in a week? Maybe I'll be an astronaut! Cross your fingers, guys!

As many of you know, last night was the Arrested Development "season" finale. This was an emotional night for me. I've praised the show, I've fought for it; fuck, I even signed an online petition, which is something I usually find to be exceedingly pointless. Of course, those efforts proved to be worthwhile, as FOX agreed to air a third season of Arrested Development. It's safe to say none of this would have happened without my one signature on that e-petition. So, needless to say, I have a special connection with the third season of Arrested Development, which came to a close last night.

But first, if you look back to the first line of this entry, you'll notice quotes around "season". That's because the third season of Arrested Development is, quite possibly, the last. The show is being canceled by FOX, and, despite a very strong offer from Showtime, the creative staff isn't sure if they want to continue. Mitchell Hurwitz, the creator, has stated that the show is a lot of work, and that he feels it may have run its course. And while he's officially still "considering" continuing, the writing in the finale shows otherwise.

That said, this is by no means a bad thing. The Arrested Development season finale created one of the strongest feelings of closure I've felt since The Office finale, bringing nearly every plot point to the forefront and tying them all together. Things I ruled out as simple one-time jokes suddenly became incredibly relevant to the plot; the Arrested Development plotline, in a way, became a work of art. Seeing the finale made me want to re-watch every episode of the past three seasons to catch all the hints I missed. 

I'm not sure how Hurwitz and crew could continue the show from this point. Sure, they could go on with the plot, there are now a whole new batch of points they could expand on. But there's no denying the total feeling of completion and satisfaction that came in the final half an hour that was the finale. Honestly, as much as I'd love to be cranky and demand more upon more episodes of Arrested Development, I'd be satisfied if they stopped here, because, well, it's perfect. The show became perfect.

Also, I mean, three seasons comes out to 53 episodes. That's 26 and a half hours of near-bliss; how much more can we ask for? I compared the finale of Arrested Development to that of The Office, but I think the shows have more in common than their finales. The Office lasted a mere two seasons, giving a total of 12 episodes. That was it. And yet I firmly believe it's one of the strongest shows to ever be on TV. Why? Because in those 12 episodes, it managed to create a concrete, brilliant plot. It didn't need anymore. Arrested Development has done the same over 53 episodes. While I'd be up for more, I don't feel it "needs" it. This isn't like Firefly, which got nipped in the bud. Arrested Development had the chance to, well, develop.

So I bid you a possible farewell, Arrested Development. It ain't easy bein' white, it ain't easy bein' brown; it ain't easy bein' the most underrated television show in town.

We showed up to class five minutes late. Not that bad of a start, I guess. We didn't miss much. Also, we didn't have a planisphere, which we were apparently supposed to buy from the bookstore, so we had to ask the TA if we could borrow his. This was, of course, after a few minutes of heated debate of the pronunciation of "planisphere". I didn't want to look like an idiot (this would happen later) when I asked him, and I could've sworn it was "planETsphere" (that makes sense, like, you know, planets? stars? it seemed reasonable at the time), but I eventually bought into Ashley's "planisphere" theory. Alright, I really shouldn't update on an empty stomach, but I'm holding off until dinner and I've got nothing better to do. So if my sentences aren't perfectly structured, or if I slip into elaborate prose about how much I enjoy Pop Tarts, please forgive me. Last night was cool, but last day... not so much. I had to make the mighty car pilgrimage to the SAC to get my car to take Fiddler on the Roof back to Family Video. And it became much colder, windier, and snowier than I was expecting. But it was nothing that I couldn't handle - when a late fee is on the line, I can take anything. But here's the thing: It wasn't the cold, wind, or snow that really got to me; it was this one guy in the parking lot. I was scraping the snow off my car like usual, doing everything I can to keep my hands from going completely numb, and this guy came driving up behind me. And it wasn't like he just drove by; he slowed. He slowed to a crawl. And he and the two other people in his car were looking at me with goofy grins on their faces. I just can not figure out what I did to get that reaction. I was scraping off my car, nothing more. I still had my iPod on and I was using my headphones as earmuffs, is that funny? What about stopping every few seconds to try to get some feeling back in my hands because I don't own gloves, is that hilarious? I just don't get it, and it's eating me up inside. Anyway, I can't let that guy get the best of me. I managed to move on through the day, I can manage to move on through this entry. A few hours, one movie return, and a dinner later... Friiiiiiiiiiiiiiday night! This is the first Friday night I've spent at Central in ages. I don't think I've spent a whole weekend up here since Jim Gaffigan late last September. I've been too busy hanging out with best-buddy Gustav, eleven or so members of Broken Social Scene, the five members of Wolf Parade hammered out of their minds, and all other kinds of happening folk; it's about time I've taken a little time to experience the party town of Mt. Pleasant. Around 8:30 or so I decided to head out to Cory's room to see if there was something we could do, but he was thoroughly engaged in the TV Edit of Scream 2. I had nothing better to do, so I decided to join in, piecing the ridiculous plot together as I went. There was some great TV Edit moments, but it was still no Pulp Fiction. Regardless, "Freaker" stands as one of the best TV curses of all time. The movie ended and Cory and myself decided to head out to the Muncherie to blow some flex bucks on nasty greasy crap, but what did we smell in the hallway? Certainly not nasty greasy crap. I couldn't tell if it was brownies, cake, or maybe even both, but we decided to carry on to the Muncherie anyway. We got our food (mozerella sticks and cheese bread; a very hearty serving of greasy dairy), and all of the sudden two girls popped in the room and invited us to have cake and brownies. I don't think I stopped giving a double thumbs-up throughout the entire conversation. So we wound up in their room, eating their brownies and cake, sitting in their chairs. They had a few other people over, but I feel I gave back the most, leaving them with a ten cent deposit on a can of Mountain Dew I was drinking. We wound up watching Saw, which I had never seen. Honestly, it wasn't really that bad. I wouldn't say it's as great as Brooke or Jaime or whoever was ranting about it end of last year was making it out to be, but it was a decently entertaining B horror-film. Se7en beats the pants off it in every regard; the director of Saw is undoubtedly guilty of envy toward the director of Se7en. Also, as it turns out, one of the girls I met was very into the same music as me; and as we know, around Central, that's a very hard statement to make if you don't love country. We wound up talking about concerts, and I told her about seeing Broken Social Scene fourth row and Arcade Fire front row, and she wound up calling one of her friends at 1:30 in the morning to tell her. After having met a dozen "what's it?"s, "who"s, and "fuckin' swedish, for real?"s around campus when I've talked about going to concerts, seeing a reaction that has any sort of excitement, let alone THAT much excitement, is fantastic. She met a very prompt facebook friends addition, bringing the total number of people at Central who like the same music as me to about, say, six. And if all that wasn't enough, I met my favorite drunk people on the way back to my hall. Drunk people can be annoying at times, but not these guys. These guys are the real deal. And they were eating snow and slipping all over the ice, so it was a good time. PS: Man, I really enjoy Pop-Tarts.

But here are some things I can tell you about:

If you recall late last August (and if you don't, you're not spending nearly as many hours on my journal as you should), I talked about getting the mole on my forehead removed. Well, last Friday, I went with it. There's currently a red mark that looks pretty much exactly like a mole, but in about two weeks, I will have one of the cleanest foreheads around. And just think of all the ways I can part my hair and have it look slightly less goofy!

And speaking of hair, my hair is well on its way to becoming a mane. The hours a day I spend tending to it will soon pay off.

I got a new winter jacket, finally. I've been wearing that cheap lightweight jacket for too long. While it started out strong with a random compliment from some girl a couple of rooms over, it was time to move onto something warmer. And it's actually interesting how it played out: I've never been a big fan of the Gap. In fact, I've probably made a couple of 'pffts' anytime after anybody said "the gap". But I went in there for the first time with Kyle and Leah when we went mallratting on Saturday, and honestly.... it's not that bad. Their shirts, pants, and nearly everything but jackets cost way more than anybody should ever spend, but they had a really wicked long wool coat for 90 bucks. And I've been in the market for a winter coat for about three months now, so I went for it. 

First time in the Gap, and I blew ninety bucks. You win, overpriced clothing chains of America.

But, as part of their promotion, they also gave me a fifteen dollar gift card because my purchase was so expensive. Which is devious, because there's nothing in that store that costs less than 25 bucks, but I'd feel bad if I didn't spend that 15 on something, so they just sucked at least another 10 bucks out of me. I was going to use it on a scarf, but I managed to find one in the closet, so now I have, you could say, a 15 dollar shopping spree! So how should I spend it?! I could use a pair of gloves. Or a hat. Or... what else do they have in that store? How should I blow that 15 bucks? You decide, readers!

Also, they dragged me into American Eagle for the first time ever, and while I still stand by everything in that store costing too much, they were playing "Christmas at the Zoo" by the Flaming Lips on their radio, which was a nice break from the same Christmas songs I've been hearing in every mall since early November. So they've earned a couple of points on the Brian scale. Not nearly points to justify a purchase; if the Brian scale was, say, a real scale, they'd weigh in at the same weight I was after my surgery.

I saved the best for last. Clear out the number one slot on your speed dial, because....

I'm getting a cell phone!

.... Maybe!

My dad's work offers a pretty cheap family plan, so he said he'd get me a cell phone and pay for a year of service for Christmas this year. This would be handy, as, you know, sometimes I'd like not to be distanced from all of the outside world. But here's the catch: It's Cingular, and I'm not sure if it'll get service in Mt. Pleasant. So if you have Cingular, let me know how it works around here so I can get back to my dad on whether to get it or not.

Or, if you know anything cell phones at all, is Cingular a good one? 

If you could stop scrolling for a second and answer this question, it would be greatly appreciated.
